page.title: Arab lobby in the United States

revision.text:
The '''Arab lobby in the United States''' is a collection of formal and informal groups and professional lobbyists paid directly by Arab governments or Arab Citizens in the United States that [[lobbyist|lobby]] the public and government of the United States on behalf of [[Arab]] interests<ref name=INFLUENCE>Mark N. Katz,[http://www.metimes.com/Opinion/2006/07/03/viewpoint_where_is_the_arab_lobby/1650/ Viewpoint: Where is the Arab lobby?] Middle East Times. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> and/or on behalf of [[Arab American]] rights in the United States.<ref name=Samhan>[http://www.aaiusa.org/foundation/358/arab-americans Arab Americans by Helen Samhan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408173059/http://www.aaiusa.org/foundation/358/arab-americans |date=2008-04-08 }}, originally published in the [[Grolier Multimedia Encyclopedia]].</ref><ref name=Puder>Joseph Puder, [http://www.thebulletin.us/site/news.cfm?newsid=18823821&BRD=2737&PAG=461&dept_id=576361&rfi=6 The Arab Lobby Can't Buy Support]{{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, The Bulletin, Philadelphia, September 17, 2007.</ref>
==Origins== According to [[Mitchell Bard]] in an article for the [[Jewish Virtual Library]], [[Isaiah L. Kenen]], the founder of [[American Zionist Committee for Public Affairs]] or "AZCPA" (which became [[American Israel Public Affairs Committee]] or "AIPAC"), wrote of the Arab lobby's roots in the 1950s "petro-diplomatic complex" that comprised the "[[Petroleum industry|oil industry]], missionaries, and diplomats." Bard states that in 1951 [[Saud of Saudi Arabia|King Saud]] of [[Saudi Arabia]] asked U.S. diplomats to finance a pro-Arab lobby to counter AZCPA.<ref name=JVLMitchellBard>"[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/US-Israel/lobby.html The Israeli and Arab Lobbies]", [[Mitchell Bard]], [[Jewish Virtual Library]], published 2006, accessed August 26, 2006.</ref> Bard in his book ''[[The Arab Lobby: The Invisible Alliance That Undermines America's Interests in the Middle East]]'', states that the approach has not changed since the days of King Saud;<ref>Bard (2010) p.66–70</ref> the basic message, according to Bard, is that the Saudis and other [[Arab States of the Persian Gulf]] have the oil and will supply it to America and its allies on the condition that America keeps the Arab ruling families in power.<ref>Bard (2010) p.344–47</ref> Bard further states that the subsidiary clause is that the Arab oil states will also purchase arms ($100 billion worth over the last 50 years) to keep themselves in power and able to produce oil.<ref name=Wisse>Ruth Wisse, [http://www.jidaily.com/sFg/e "A Tale of Two Lobbies,"], review of [[Mitchell Bard]]'s ''[[The Arab Lobby: The Invisible Alliance That Undermines America's Interests in the Middle East|The Arab Lobby]]'', ''[[Jewish Ideas Daily]]'', September 8, 2010.</ref>
Bard also alleges "[[blackmail]]" . He claims that from time to time the United States criticized the oil states for denying human rights to their own citizens, sponsoring militants who attack Israel, spreading extremist forms of Islam around the world, and supporting terrorism in many countries, but this criticism in rapidly reined in by threatening to cut off the oil supply.<ref name=Wisse/>
The [[National Association of Arab-Americans]] ("NAAA"), founded in 1972, was a political advocacy group whose goals were "to strengthen U.S. relations with Arab countries and to promote an evenhanded American policy based on justice and peace for all parties in the Middle East."<ref>[http://www.cafearabica.com/organizations/org12/orgnaaa.html CafeArabica.com page on NAAA.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080306021052/http://www.cafearabica.com/organizations/org12/orgnaaa.html |date=March 6, 2008}}</ref> In the early 1970s there was growing [[anti-Arab]] sentiment related to the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]] and the [[1973 oil crisis|1973 oil embargo]], leading to government investigations, [[Executive order (United States)|executive orders]], and legislative provisions to combat terrorism. These especially impacted on Arab American rights and activism. The response was the creation of groups like the [[Association of Arab-American University Graduates]], the [[American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee]] and the [[Arab American Institute]].<ref name=Samhan/>
According to Michael Lewis, Director of Policy Analysis for the [[American Israel Public Affairs Committee]], for many years these groups worked together on the Palestinian issue, including through newspaper, direct mail and advertising campaigns against U.S. loan guarantees to Israel and states' purchase of Israel bonds, condemnation of Israeli human rights and calls for the U.S. government to pressure Israel, as well pro-Palestinian protests and letter-writing campaigns. Lewis states that they also offered testimony to congress and criticized Israel's congressional and organizational supporters, sought to pass pro-Palestinian resolutions in state and national party platforms; offering pro-Palestinian testimony before Congress and attempted to sue Israel in U.S. courts. According to Lewis after the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] had reached an agreement with Israel, there was some division among the groups, however they continue to lobby for Palestinians.<ref>Michael Lewis, [http://www.meforum.org/article/372 Israel's American Detractors - Back Again], ''[[Middle East Quarterly]]'', December 1997.</ref>
==Lobbying by Arab states== Many of the players in the Arab lobby are paid directly by Arab governments. ''[[The New York Times]]'' describes them as an "elite band of former members of Congress, former diplomats and power brokers who have helped Middle Eastern nations navigate diplomatic waters here on delicate issues like arms deals, terrorism, oil and trade restrictions." Powerful lobbyists working on behalf of the Arab lobby include [[Bob Livingston]], [[Tony Podesta]], and [[Toby Moffett]]. Arab governments have paid "tens of millions of dollars" to "top" lobbying firms that work to influence the American government.<ref name="Lichtblau">Eric Lichtblau, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/world/middleeast/02lobby.html?scp=1&sq=arab%20lobby&st=cse Arab Unrest Puts Their Lobbyists in Uneasy Spot], ''The New York Times'', March 1, 2011.</ref> This includes the [[Saudi Arabia lobby]], [[Egypt lobby]] and the [[Libya lobby]].
In the wake of 9/11, Saudi Arabia hired the lobbying firms [[Patton Boggs]] and [[Qorvis]], paying $14 million a year.<ref name="Lichtblau"/><ref name="Putting Lipstick on a Dictator">{{cite news|last=Kurlantzick|first=Joshua|title=Putting Lipstick on a Dictator|work=Mother Jones|date=2007-05-07|url=https://www.motherjones.com/news/outfront/2007/05/extreme_makeover.html |accessdate=2007-08-22}}</ref>
Lobby fees paid by Arab governments to individual firms "commonly" reach levels of $50,000 and above. In 2009 alone the [[United Arab Emirates]] spent $5.3 million, as the Emirates were seeking nuclear technology. In 2009 Morocco spent $3 million and [[Algeria]] spent $600,000 on Washington, D.C. lobbyists, and Turkey spent $1.7 million. According to [[Howard Marlowe]], president of the [[American League of Lobbyists]], "These kinds of regimes have a lot of money at their disposal, and that'’s a great attraction."<ref name="Lichtblau"/>
According to [[ProPublica]], 4 of the top 10 governments lobbying in Washington are Arab, in terms of spending. The [[United Arab Emirates]] places first, having spent $10,914,002 in 2007 and 2008. Iraq, Morocco and Saudi Arabia also each spent over $3 million, and the non-Arab, Middle Eastern nation of [[Turkish lobby in the United States|Turkey]] also spent over $3 million.<ref>Anupama Narayanswamy and Luke Rosiak, [https://www.propublica.org/article/adding-it-up-the-top-players-in-foreign-agent-lobbying-718 Adding it up: The Top Players in Foreign Agent Lobbying], [[ProPublica]], August 18, 2009.</ref>
In June 2017, [[Qatar]] began a "massive lobbying campaign" in the U.S. after President Donald Trump sided with Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and other Arab countries in imposing a blockade against Qatar. Through August 2018, "Qatar has hired 35 US lobbying firms and paid them a total of at least $19.5 million." According to disclosure filings, "The lobbyists contacted hundreds of members of the US Congress and dozens of journalists and Trump administration officials while spending millions of dollars on advertising that promotes Qatar as a US ally."<ref>{{cite news |date=August 5, 2018 |title=Accusations, lawsuits challenge Qatar’s multimillion-dollar lobbying, 'damage control' PR |url=https://thearabweekly.com/accusations-lawsuits-challenge-qatars-multimillion-dollar-lobbying-damage-control-pr |work=The Arab Weekly }}</ref> Lobbyists hired by Qatar include Trump fundraiser Brian Ballard of Ballard Partners and former attorney general [[John Ashcroft]].<ref>{{cite news |date=April 9, 2018 |title=Qatar hires Trump-linked lobbyist ahead of emir's visit |url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2018/04/qatar-hires-trump-linked-lobbyist-emir-visit.html |agency=Al-Monitor }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=June 10, 2017 |title=Qatar, accused of supporting terrorism, hires ex-U.S. attorney general |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-ashcroft-idUSKBN1910T6 |agency=Reuters }}</ref> [[Mohammed bin Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]], brother of the Emir of Qatar, is alleged to be directing the U.S. lobbying campaign.<ref>{{cite news |date=May 24, 2018 |title=Trump fundraiser expands U.S. lawsuit accusing Qatar of hacking his emails |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-trump-russia-qatar/trump-fundraiser-expands-us-lawsuit-accusing-qatar-of-hacking-his-emails-idUSL2N1SV1AD |agency=Reuters }}</ref>
==Arab American civil rights and advocacy groups== The [[American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee]] (ADC) was started in 1980 by [[United States Senator]] [[James Abourezk]]. It is the largest Arab American grassroots civil rights organization in the United States. Former [[United States Congressman|US Congresswoman]] [[Mary Rose Oakar]] is the current president. ADC is at the forefront in addressing [[anti-Arabism]] - discrimination and bias against Arab Americans. It also advocates what it calls a more balanced US policy towards the Middle East.<ref>[http://www.adc.org American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee web page]</ref>
The Arab American Institute ("AAI"), founded in 1985 by [[James Zogby]], is a non-profit, membership organization and advocacy group based in Washington D.C. that focuses on the issues and interests of Arab American nationwide. The organization seeks to increase the visibility of Arab American involvement as voters and candidates in the American political system. It issues "Action Alerts" and encourages individual lobbying and participation in an annual national lobby day. It has promoted actively professors [[John Mearsheimer]] and [[Stephen Walt]]'s book [[The Israel Lobby and U.S. Foreign Policy]].<ref>[http://www.aaiusa.org/press-room/3431/walt-and-mearsheimer-to-appear-on-viewpoint-this-thursday You can still watch Walt and Mearsheimer on 'Viewpoint'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221200833/http://www.aaiusa.org/press-room/3431/walt-and-mearsheimer-to-appear-on-viewpoint-this-thursday |date=2007-12-21 }} on the AAI website.</ref>
==Informal Arab lobby== According to Bard, author of 2010 book ''The Arab Lobby: The Invisible Alliance That Undermines America's Interests in the Middle East'', the informal Arab lobby includes tens of millions of dollars donated to American Universities for Islamic studies, because these funds flow only to universities that teach courses and hire scholars whose work meets with the approval of the oil states, courses are not offered and research is not pursued on the ideology or structure radical Islam, Arab anti-Americanism, or Arab anti-Semitism, instead, courses are taught and studies pursued on such themes as Zionism as an illegitimate political movement, or form of European imperialism, and Jewishness is a largely mythological and invented history.<ref name=Wisse/><ref>Mitchell Bard, ''The Arab Lobby,'' "The Abuse of Academic Freedom; The Lobby Infiltrates the Classroom," Chapter 14, pp. 284-321.</ref>
==Power of lobby== Bard, author of 2010 book ''The Arab Lobby'' and a former editor of the "Near East Report", a weekly newsletter published by the [[American Israel Public Affairs Committee]], writes that "from the beginning, the Arab lobby has faced not only a disadvantage in electoral politics but also in organization."<ref name=JVLMitchellBard/> Academics [[Ali A. Mazrui]] and Nabeel A. Khoury have also written about the virtual non-existence of an Arab lobby in America.<ref>See Ali A. Mazrui, “Between the Crescent and the Star Spangled Banner: American Muslims and U.S. Foreign Policy,” International Affairs, Vol. 72, No. 3 (July 1996), 493-506; Nabeel A. Khoury, “The Arab Lobby: Problems and Prospects,” [[Middle East Journal]], Vol. 41, No. 3 (Summer 1987), 379-396; Andrea Barron, “Jewish and Arab Diasporas in the United States and Their Impact on U.S. Middle East Policy,” in Yehuda Lukacs and Abdalla M. Battah, eds., The Arab Israeli Conflict: Two Decades of Change (London: Westview, 1988), 238-259.</ref>
In a 2007 [[State Department]] Foreign Press Center Briefing [[James Zogby]] of the Arab American Institute denied [[Arab Americans]] lobby for Arab governments. He told an audience: "There are many Arab lobbies. Each Arab government hires lobbyists to do their work for them. And we Arab Americans are not an Arab lobby. I think that the thing in the Jewish community that's interesting is that the Jewish community is supportive of Israel and the Israeli Government works very closely with elements in the American Jewish community around a convergence of ideas and issues and interests, and that has created the sense of an Israel lobby." Zogby also said "The reality about Arab Americans is that we are emerging as a political group."<ref>[http://2002-2009-fpc.state.gov/95931.htm "Arab Americans and the Middle East Policy in the 2008 U.S. Elections"], Dr. James Zogby, President of the Arab American Institute Foreign Press Center Briefing, Washington, DC November 29, 2007</ref>
Researchers Sherri Replogle and Khalil Marrar write: "While pro-Arab lobbying pales in comparison to those of the pro-Israel lobby, the end of the Cold-War, the current war on terrorism, and clear American and international support for the two-state solution as manifested by public opinion polls, policymakers' statements, and United Nations Security Council Resolutions [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1397|1397]] and [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1515|1515]], provide the pro-Arab lobby with a crucial opportunity to realize its vision of Palestinian statehood."<ref>"The Effects of the Pro-Arab Lobby on American Foreign Policy in the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict" Paper presented at the annual meeting of the International Studies Association 48th Annual Convention, Hilton Chicago, CHICAGO, IL, USA, Feb 28, 2007</ref>
In 2010 lobbyists paid by the government of Egypt succeeded in preventing the Senate from passing a bill calling on Egypt to curtail human rights abuses.<ref name="Lichtblau"/>
==See also==

The '''Association of Manitoba Municipalities''' (AMM) is an organization of municipal governments in the province of [[Manitoba]], [[Canada]]. All municipalities in Manitoba are members.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Goldsborough |first=Gordon |year=2006 |title=A Union of Manitoba Municipalities |journal=Manitoba History |publisher=[[Manitoba Historical Society]] |issue=51 |pages= |issn=0226-5036 |url=http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/mb_history/51/municipalunion.shtml }}</ref>
The AMM was founded in 1999, by a merger of the Union of Manitoba Municipalities (UMM) and the Manitoba Association of Urban Municipalities (MAUM). Its stated purpose is to identify and address "the needs and concerns of its members in order to achieve strong and effective municipal government".
==See also== *[[List of micro-regional organizations]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.amm.mb.ca AMM Website]

'''Boundaries'''—particularly field boundaries—are among the oldest features in an English rural landscape.<ref>English Heritage http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/hc2006/upload/pdf/eastofengland2004.pdf</ref> Although a boundary itself is an abstract concept, the boundary can often be seen by differences in land use on either side.
==Longevity of boundaries== Boundaries- a real or imagined line that marks the limit of something. Many field boundaries in the central region of England originated with the [[enclosure]] of the previous open fields in the 18th or 19th centuries. In a few instances, current field boundaries (particularly in the west country) have been shown to have originated in the Bronze Age or Iron Age. With a few exceptions, however, the attempt to establish pre-Saxon boundaries has been "largely fruitless".<ref>{{cite book|first=Della|last=Hooke|title=The landscape of Anglo-Saxon England|publisher=Leicester University Press|year=1998|page=63}}</ref> Areas that were never formally enclosed might yet prove a more fruitful area of research.
==Hedgerow dating== The presence of [[Common bluebell|bluebells]] in a hedge is often an indicator of an early hedge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsparch.org.uk/resources/Archaeobotany.pdf|title=Archaeobotany or plants in the 4th dimension|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401041050/http://www.bsparch.org.uk/resources/Archaeobotany.pdf|archivedate=2010-04-01|df=}}</ref> It has been proposed that boundary hedges can be dated by [[Hooper's Rule|hedgerow dating]]. This involves counting the number of species in a 27-metre section of hedge. In its simplest form each separate species suggests an age of 100 years. A variety of additional complexities have been suggested, but results have been mixed and the technique remains controversial.
==Parish boundaries== Parish boundaries are of particular interest to [[landscape history|landscape historians]], since they are often inherited from land holdings that date back to the middle Saxon period or earlier. The coincidence of another landscape feature with a parish boundary can be used to date that feature—for example in the ''[[Time Team]]'' episode screened on 11 March 2007, a mill leat was determined to pre-date the [[Norman conquest of England|Norman conquest]] because it coincided with a parish boundary.
The boundaries of a few Anglo-Saxon estates were described in the boundary clauses of [[Anglo-Saxon Charters]]. These boundary clauses can sometimes be used to characterise the landscape at the time. In some cases, it has been possible to show that the boundaries of these Anglo-Saxon estates correspond to the boundaries of the subsequent parish.
Parish boundaries are shown on the old "1 inch" [[Ordnance Survey]] maps, although these are the boundaries of the civil parish which may be different. Parish boundaries are not shown on the modern "Landranger" maps. [[Tithe maps]], from the early 19th century, usually show the parish boundary at the time they were drawn.
== March dyke == [[File:March dyke sourlie.JPG|right|thumb|160px|<center>The old march dyke between the baronies of [[Eglinton Country Park|Eglinton]] and Stone in North Ayrshire.]] In Scotland a march dyke is the boundary between farms or previously baronies.
==Deer park boundaries== The boundaries of [[medieval deer park]]s are often marked by pronounced [[Earthworks (Archaeology)|earthworks]]<ref>Richard Muir, ''Be Your Own Landscape Detective'' (Sutton Publishing, 2007, p245)</ref> and for early parks, they can coincide with parish boundaries.
==Former boundaries== Boundaries that have fallen out of use, may still be traceable by using [[Archaeological geophysics|geophysics]] or as a result of earthworks (lumps and bumps) or [[cropmark]]s. Cropmarks and earthworks are often visible in [[aerial photography|aerial photographs]]. Earthworks are more easily seen on photographs taken when the sun is low in the sky and as a result, shadows are more pronounced. They can also become more easily seen when the ground has a slight dusting of snow.

Lower Craigton|city=
Milngavie |pocode=[[G postcode area|G62 7HQ]] |nation=Scotland}} |newspaper= |youth_wing= |position = [[Far-right]] |ideology= |european= |international= |europarl= |colours={{Colourbox|{{Britannica Party/meta/color}}}} Blue |slogan= |seats1_title = [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|650|{{Britannica Party/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = [[House of Lords]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|724|{{Britannica Party/meta/color}}}} |seats8_title = [[Local government in the United Kingdom|Local government]] |seats8 = {{Composition bar|0|21259|{{Britannica Party/meta/color}}}} |website= |country=United Kingdom }} '''Britannica''' is a [[far-right]]{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/aug/19/far-right-fragmenting-bnp|title=The far right is fragmenting|last=Goodwin|first=Matthew|date=19 August 2012|accessdate=5 May 2014|work=The Guardian}}{{cite web|url=http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/blogs/searchlight-blog/britannica-party-fields-four-candidates|title=Britannica Party fields four candidates|work=Searchlight|last=Gable|first=Sonia|date=8 April 2012|accessdate=13 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113035745/http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/blogs/searchlight-blog/britannica-party-fields-four-candidates|archivedate=13 November 2013|df=}}{{cite news|last=Beaton|first=Connor|url=http://thetarge.co.uk/article/current-affairs/0302/bnp-splinter-starts-antiindy-campaign|title=BNP splinter joins anti-indy campaign|date=21 June 2014|accessdate=22 June 2014|work=The Targe}} [[political party]] in the [[United Kingdom]], led by Charles Baillie, the former organiser of the [[British National Party]]'s [[Glasgow]] branch. It was first registered in August 2011.{{cite web|url=http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/English/Registrations/PP1803|title=Britannica Party|work=Electoral Commission|accessdate=22 April 2017}} The party was formed by Baillie when he, along with other leading members of the BNP in Scotland, was expelled for plotting against the then party leader, [[Nick Griffin]]. It is, in essence, the core of the BNP Glasgow branch, including Max Dunbar (treasurer and former treasurer of BNP Glasgow), Jean Douglas and Martin Clark. John Robertson, the BNP "security officer" for the Highlands & Islands, is also a member.[http://www.glasgowhopenothate.org/britannicaparty.html "Britannica Party"], Hope not Hate. Retrieved 17 July 2017. ==Electoral performance== The party stood four candidates at the [[Glasgow City Council election, 2012]], receiving a total of 73 votes. It also stood at three council by-elections in Glasgow, in [[Hillhead (ward)|Hillhead]] (17 November 2011, 11 votes), [[Govan (ward)|Govan]] (10 October 2013, 19 votes) and [[Shettleston (ward)|Shettleston]] (5 December 2013, 31 votes). It registered with the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] as campaigning for a "No" vote in the [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014]].[http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/find-information-by-subject/elections-and-referendums/upcoming-elections-and-referendums/scottish-referendum/register-of-campaigners-at-the-scottish-independence-referendum Register of permitted participants at the referendum on independence for Scotland], Electoral Commission. The party does not appear to have grown, but its accounts have been regularly filed with the Electoral Commission, showing income for 2015 and 2016 respectively of 4p and 3p, with the only expenditure in both years being the annual £50 registration fee to the Commission.[http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/Search/Accounts?currentPage=1&rows=10&query=britannica&sort=PublishedDate&order=desc&et=pp&et=ppm&et=tp&et=perpar&et=rd®ister=gb®ister=ni®ister=none®Status=registered&rptBy=centralparty&rptBy=accountingunits&optCols=PublishedDate&optCols=FinancialYearEnd&optCols=BandName&optCols=SoaType Britannica] - search at Electoral Commission. Retrieved 7 May 2018. == References == {{Reflist}} {{UK-party-stub}} [[Category:Far-right political parties in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Political parties in Scotland]] [[Category:2011 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2011]] [[Category:Politics of Glasgow]] [[Category:British National Party breakaway groups]]

{{Infobox civilian attack | title = Cairo fire/Black Saturday | image = Cairo Fire 1952 Rivoli Cinema.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = A crowd of bystanders stands outside a burning building, with black smoke coming out of the windows. | caption = Rivoli Cinema on fire | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] | target = Buildings owned by or associated with Europeans | coordinates = {{Coord|30|3|29|N|31|13|44|E|display=inline,title}} | date = {{Start date|1952|01|26|df=y}} | time-begin = 12:30 pm | time-end = 11 pm | timezone = [[UTC+02:00]] | type = [[Riot]]s, [[arson]] | fatalities = 26<ref name="Ahram Damage">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/457/55/Malafat.aspx |script-title=ar:خسائر الحريق |date=12 May 2010 |journal=[[Al-Ahram]] |trans-title=The Fire Damage |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512021201/http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/457/55/Malafat.aspx |archivedate=2011-05-12 |df= }}</ref> (inc. 9 Britons)<ref name="King 208">[[#Kin89|King 1989]], p. 208</ref> | injuries = 552<ref name="Ahram Damage"/> | perp = Unknown ([[#Conspiracy theories|several theories]]) }} The '''Cairo fire''' ({{Lang-ar|حريق القاهرة}}), also known as '''Black Saturday''',<ref name="King 207">[[#Kin89|King 1989]], p. 207</ref><ref name="Goldschmidt">[[#Gol04|Goldschmidt & Johnston 2004]], p. 83</ref> was a series of [[riot]]s that took place on 26 January 1952, marked by the burning and looting of some 750 buildings<ref name="RebellionWright">[http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2008/06/02/080602fa_fact_wright?currentPage=all The Rebellion Within, An Al Qaeda mastermind questions terrorism. by Lawrence Wright. newyorker.com, June 2, 2008]</ref>—retail shops, cafes, cinemas, hotels, restaurants, theatres, nightclubs, and the city's [[Cairo Opera House|Opera House]]—in [[downtown Cairo]]. The direct trigger of the riots was the killing by British occupation troops of 50 Egyptian [[auxiliary police]]men in the city of [[Ismaïlia]] in a one-sided battle a day earlier.<ref name="Goldschmidt"/> The spontaneous anti-British protests that followed these deaths were quickly seized upon by organized elements in the crowd, who burned and ransacked large sectors of Cairo amidst the unexplained absence of security forces.<ref name="King 207"/> The fire is thought by some to have signalled the end of the [[History of modern Egypt#Kingdom of Egypt|Kingdom of Egypt]].<ref name="RebellionWright"/><ref>''Egypt on the Brink'' by Tarek Osman, Yale University Press, 2010, p.39</ref> The perpetrators of the Cairo Fire remain unknown to this day, and the truth about this important event in modern Egyptian history has yet to be established.<ref name="Hassan">{{Cite journal |last=Hassan |first=Fayza |date=24–30 January 2002 |title=Burning down the house |journal=[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] |issue=570 |accessdate=2011-02-06 |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2002/570/sc3.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091108034353/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2002/570/sc3.htm# |archive-date=2009-11-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The disorder that befell Cairo during the 1952 fire has recently been compared to the chaos that followed the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|anti-government protests of 28 January 2011]], which saw demonstrations take place amidst massive arson and looting, an inexplicable withdrawal of the police and organized prison-breaking.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Muhammad |first=Mohsen |date=3 February 2011 |script-title=ar:خسارة |trans-title=Khusara |journal=[[Al Gomhuria]] |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-06 |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/views/2011/02/03/136071.html |format=Reprint}}</ref>
==Background== In 1952, the [[British occupation of Egypt]] was entering its 70th year, but was limited to the [[Suez Canal]] zone. On the morning of 25 January 1952, Brigadier [[Kenneth Exham]], the British commander, issued a warning to Egyptian policemen in Ismaïlia, demanding that they surrender their weapons and leave the canal zone entirely. By doing so, the British aimed to get rid of the only manifestation of Egyptian governmental authority in the canal zone. They also wanted to end the aid the police force was providing to anti-British [[Fedayeen#Egypt|''fedayeen'' groups]]. The [[Ismailia Governorate]] refused the British request, a refusal that was reiterated by interior minister [[Fouad Serageddin]]. As a result, 7,000 British soldiers equipped with [[machine gun]]s, [[tank]]s and [[armour]] surrounded the governorate building and its [[barracks]], containing nearly 700 Egyptian officers and soldiers. Armed only with [[rifle]]s, the Egyptians refused to surrender their weapons. The British commander thus ordered his troops to bombard the buildings. Vastly outnumbered, the Egyptians continued to fight until they ran out of [[ammunition]]. The confrontation, which lasted two hours, left 50 Egyptians dead and 80 others injured. The rest were taken captive.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/455/55/Malafat.aspx |script-title=ar:معركة الاسماعيلية |date=13 May 2010 |journal=[[Al-Ahram]] |trans-title=The Battle of Ismaïlia |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-04 |title=Archived copy |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512021601/http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/455/55/Malafat.aspx# |archive-date=2011-05-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Events== The following day, news of the attack in Ismaïlia reached Cairo, provoking the ire of Egyptians. The unrest began at [[Almaza Air Base|Almaza Airport]], when workers there refused to provide services to four British airplanes. It was followed by the rebellion of policemen in the [[Abbassia|Abbaseya]] barracks, who wished to express their solidarity with their dead and captured colleagues in Ismaïlia. Protesters then headed towards the university building, where they were joined by students. Together they marched towards the prime minister's office to demand that Egypt break its [[Egypt – United Kingdom relations|diplomatic relations]] with the [[United Kingdom]] and declare war on it. [[Abdul Fattah Hassan]], the Minister of Social Affairs, told them that the [[Wafd Party|Wafdist]] government wished to do so, but faced opposition from King [[Farouk of Egypt|Farouk I]]. As a result, protesters went to [[Abdeen Palace]] where they were joined by students from [[Al-Azhar University|Al-Azhar]]. The crowd expressed its discontent towards the king, his partisans and the British.<ref name="Ahram Events">{{Cite journal |url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/456/55/Malafat.aspx |script-title=ar:حريق القاهرة 1952 |date=12 May 2010 |journal=[[Al-Ahram]] |trans-title=The 1952 Cairo Fire |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-04 |title=Archived copy |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512021212/http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/456/55/Malafat.aspx# |archive-date=2011-05-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
The first act of [[arson]] took place in Opera Square, with the burning of Casino Opera. The fire spread to [[Shepheard's Hotel]], the Automobile Club, [[Barclays]] Bank, as well as other shops, corporate offices, movie theaters, hotels and banks.<ref name="Ahram Events"/> Fueled by [[Anti-British sentiment|anti-British]] and [[anti-Western sentiment]], the mob concentrated on British property and establishments with foreign connections,<ref name="King 207"/> as well as buildings popularly associated with [[Westernization|Western influence]].<ref name="Goldschmidt"/> [[Nightclub]]s and other establishments frequented by King Farouk I were equally targeted. The fires also reached the neighbourhoods of [[Faggala]], [[Daher, Egypt|Daher]], [[Cairo Citadel|Citadel]], as well as [[Tahrir Square]] and Cairo Train Station Square. Due to the prevailing chaos, theft and looting occurred, until the [[Egyptian Army]] arrived shortly before sunset and managed to restore order.<ref name="Ahram Events"/> The Army was alerted belatedly, after most of the damage had already occurred.<ref name="King 207"/>
==Damage== Most of the destruction, the extent of which was unforeseen by everyone,<ref name="King 207"/> occurred between 12:30 pm and 11 pm.<ref name="Ahram Damage"/> A total of £3.4 million damage was done to British and foreign property.<ref name="King 207"/> Nearly 300 shops were destroyed, including some of Egypt's most famous [[department store]]s, such as Cicurel, Omar Effendi and the Salon Vert. The damage tally also included 30 corporate offices, 13 [[hotel]]s (among which Shepheard's, Metropolitan and Victoria), 40 [[movie theater]]s (among which Rivoli, Radio, Metro, Diana and Miami), eight [[auto show]]s, 10 firearms shops, 73 [[coffeehouse]]s and [[restaurant]]s (including Groppi's), 92 [[Bar (establishment)|bars]] and 16 [[social club]]s. As for the human casualties, 26 people died and 552 suffered injuries such as [[burn]]s and [[bone fracture]]s. Thousands of workers were displaced due to the destruction of these establishments.<ref name="Ahram Damage"/>
==Aftermath== The events were seen at the time as evidence of the Egyptian government's inability to maintain order.<ref name="Goldschmidt"/> They almost caused another British military occupation, although this outcome was averted by the Egyptian Army's restoration of order.<ref name="King 207"/> Prime Minister [[Mustafa el-Nahhas]] initially presented his resignation, which was refused by King Farouk I.<ref name="Ahram Aftermath">{{Cite journal |url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/458/55/Malafat.aspx |script-title=ar:إقالة النحاس وثورة يوليو |date=9 May 2010 |journal=[[Al-Ahram]] |trans-title=The Dismissal of el-Nahhas and the July Revolution |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-04 |title=Archived copy |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512021543/http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/458/55/Malafat.aspx# |archive-date=2011-05-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The Wafdist government of el-Nahhas and the king blamed each other for the failure to call in troops earlier.<ref name="King 207"/> The Council of Ministers imposed [[martial law]] throughout the country, and ordered the closure of schools and universities. El-Nahhas was appointed military commander-in-chief, and proclaimed a [[curfew]] in Cairo and [[Giza]] from 6 pm to 6 am. He also issued an order banning public gatherings of five or more persons, with offenders facing imprisonment.<ref name="Ahram Aftermath"/>
The king was holding a banquet at [[Abdeen Palace]] for nearly 2,000 military officers when the disturbances took place.<ref name="Ahram Aftermath"/> The banquet had been organized to celebrate the birth of his son [[Fuad II of Egypt|Ahmad Fuad]].<ref name="Hassan"/> The following day, the king dismissed the Wafdist government, a decision which slightly eased tensions with the British.<ref name="Ahram Aftermath"/> However, the series of short-lived [[Cabinet of Egypt|cabinets]] he appointed afterward failed to restore public confidence in the monarchy.<ref name="Goldschmidt"/> The resultant political and domestic instability throughout the ensuing six months was among the factors that paved the way for the [[Egyptian Revolution of 1952|Free Officers coup]].<ref name="King 208"/> The Cairo Fire pushed the [[Free Officers Movement (Egypt)|Free Officers]] to advance the date of their planned coup, which took place on 23 July 1952.<ref name="Ahram Aftermath"/> The coup resulted in the forced abdication of Farouk I and the abolition of the monarchy a year later. It also reignited anti-British hostilities, which led to the signing of the [[Anglo-Egyptian Evacuation Agreement]] in 1954. The last British soldier stationed in Egypt left the country on 18 June 1956.<ref name="Ahram Aftermath"/>
==Conspiracy theories== No one was arrested during the disorder.<ref name="Ahram Events"/> It appears that there were organized elements in the crowd, both [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] and [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]].<ref name="King 207"/> According to official sources as well as eyewitnesses, the disturbances had been masterminded beforehand, and the groups responsible for it were highly skilled and trained. This was evidenced by the speed and precision with which the fires were ignited. The perpetrators held tools to force open closed doors, and used [[Gas burner|acetylene stoves]] to melt steel barriers placed on windows and doors. They executed their plan in record time through the use of nearly 30 cars.<ref name="Ahram Perpetrators">{{Cite journal |url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/459/55/Malafat.aspx |script-title=ar:من وراء حريق القاهرة؟ |date=18 May 2010 |journal=[[Al-Ahram]] |trans-title=Who Was Behind the Cairo Fire |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-04 |title=Archived copy |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512021611/http://www.ahram.org.eg/433/2011/02/04/459/55/Malafat.aspx# |archive-date=2011-05-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The timing was also another clear indication of the careful planning behind the arson. Saturday afternoon was chosen due to the weekend closure of offices and department stores, as well as the post-matinée closure of movie theaters.<ref name="Ahram Damage"/>
Although some of the country's politicians may have been implicated in the initial outbreak of violence,<ref name="King 207"/> it has never been fully determined who started the Cairo Fire.<ref name="Goldschmidt"/> Historians still disagree about the identity of the initiators of the disturbances, leading to several [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]].<ref name="Hassan"/> Some believe King Farouk I masterminded the disorder to get rid of the government of el-Nahhas. Others support the idea that the British instigated the chaos to punish the government of el-Nahhas for its unilateral abrogation of the [[Anglo-Egyptian Treaty of 1936|Anglo-Egyptian Treaty]] in 1951.<ref name="Ahram Perpetrators"/> Alternative theories put the blame on the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] or the [[Young Egypt Party|Egyptian Socialist Party]], formerly known as ''Misr al-Fatat''.<ref name="Goldschmidt"/> Nevertheless, no material evidence has ever appeared to incriminate a specific group. Following the [[Egyptian Revolution of 1952|23 July 1952 coup]], an inquiry was opened to investigate the circumstances surrounding the Cairo Fire, but failed to identify the real perpetrators. The Cairo Fire thus remains an unsolved mystery.<ref name="Ahram Perpetrators"/>

[[File:CIDG unit training.jpg|thumb|CIDG Unit Training]] '''Civilian Irregular Defense Group program''' (CIDG, pronounced "sid-gee") was a program developed by the [[U.S. government]] in the [[Vietnam War]] to develop [[South Vietnamese]] [[irregular military]] [[military unit|unit]]s from minority populations.
==Purpose== The Civilian Irregular Defense Group program was formed for two reasons:<ref> {{cite book| url = http://www.history.army.mil/BOOKS/Vietnam/90-23/90-23C.htm | series =Vietnam Studies| title = U.S. Army Special Forces 1961-1971| id = CMH Publication 90-23| publisher = [[United States Army Center of Military History]] | location = Washington, D.C. | year = 1989 | origyear =First Printed, 1973| pages = 19–20}}</ref> #U.S. mission Saigon believed that the South Vietnamese effort to create similar [[paramilitary]] units needed to be bolstered #The U.S. feared that the Viet Cong would be able to recruit large numbers of minority troops.
==History== The CIDG program was devised by the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] in early 1961 to counter expanding [[Viet Cong]] influence in [[Tây Nguyên|South Vietnam's Central Highlands]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Learning to Eat Soup With a Knife: Counterinsurgency Lessons from Malaya and Vietnam|author=[[John Nagl]]|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=2005|isbn=9780226567709|page=128}}</ref> Beginning in the village of Buon Enao, small A Teams from the [[Special Forces (United States Army)|U.S. Army Special Forces (Green Berets)]] moved into villages and set up Area Development Centers. Focusing on local defense and civic action, the Special Forces teams did the majority of the training. Villagers were trained and armed for village defense for two weeks, while localized Strike Forces would receive better training and weapons and served as a quick reaction force to react to Viet Cong attacks. The vast majority of the CIDG camps were initially manned by inhabitants of [[ethnic minority]] regions in the country (especially [[Degar|Montagnard]]), who disliked both the [[North Vietnam|North]] and South Vietnamese and therefore quickly took to the American advisers. The program was widely successful, as once one village was pacified, it served as a training camp for other local villages.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.americanheritage.com/content/special-forces|title=Special Forces}}.</ref>
By 1963, the military felt that the program was a great success, but also that the CIDG units and Special Forces units were not being employed properly, and ordered Operation Switchback, which transferred control of the CIDG program from the CIA over to [[Military Assistance Command, Vietnam]].<ref>Nagl, p. 129</ref> The CIDG Program was rapidly expanded, as the entire [[5th Special Forces Group]], U.S. Army Special Forces, moved into Vietnam, and the CIDG units stopped focusing on village defense and instead took part in more conventional operations, most notably border surveillance. Most of these were converted to [[Vietnamese Rangers|Vietnam Army Ranger]] units in 1970.
==See also== *[[Battle of A Shau]] *[[Battle of Dong Xoai]] *[[Battle of Hiep Hoa]] *[[Battle of Kham Duc]] *[[Battle of Nam Dong]] *[[MIKE Force]] the mobile forces of the CIDG program. *[[Siege of Plei Me]] *[[Vietcong (video game)|Vietcong]] PC first-person shooter set in a CIDG camp

{{Broader|Closed-circuit television}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} [[Image:CCTV Cameras.png|thumb|Different types of CCTV cameras.]] A '''closed-circuit television camera''' ('''CCTV camera''') can produce images or recordings for [[surveillance]] or other private purposes. Cameras can be either [[video camera]]s, or [[Digital camera|digital stills cameras]]. [[Walter Bruch]] was the inventor of the CCTV camera.
== Video cameras== [[Image:CS-mount pinhole lens.jpg|thumb|right|A couple of [[C mount|CS-mount]] lenses for surveillance cameras. The left one is designed to be hidden behind a wall.]] Video cameras are either analogue or digital, which means that they work on the basis of sending [[Analog signal|analogue]] or [[Digital signal (signal processing)|digital]] signals to a storage device such as a video tape recorder or [[Personal computer|desktop computer]] or [[laptop computer]]. === Analogue === Can record straight to a [[video tape recorder]] which are able to record analogue signals as pictures. If the analogue signals are recorded to tape, then the tape must run at a very slow speed in order to operate continuously. This is because in order to allow a three-hour tape to run for 24 hours, it must be set to run on a slow time lapse basis, usually about four frames per second. In one second, the camera scene can change dramatically. A person for example can have walked a distance of 1 meter, and therefore if the distance is divided into four parts, i.e. four frames or "snapshots" in time, then each frame invariably looks like a blur, unless the subject keeps relatively still.<ref>{{cite web|title=Things to know before buying security cameras|url=https://wiredstore.com.au/2018/06/05/things-to-know-before-buying-security-cameras/}}</ref>
Analogue signals can also be [[Analog-to-digital converter|converted into a digital signal]] to enable the recordings to be stored on a PC as [[digital recording]]s. In that case the analogue video camera must be plugged directly into a [[video capture card]] in the computer, and the card then converts the analogue signal to digital. These cards are relatively cheap, but inevitably the resulting digital signals are compressed 5:1 (MPEG compression) in order for the video recordings to be saved on a continuous basis.
Another way to store recordings on a non-analogue media is through the use of a [[digital video recorder]] (DVR). Such a device is similar in functionality to a PC with a capture card and appropriate video recording [[software]]. Unlike PCs, most [[Digital video recorder#Security applications|DVRs designed for CCTV purposes]] are embedded devices that require less maintenance and simpler setup than a PC-based solution, for a medium to large number of analogue cameras.
Some DVRs also allow digital broadcasting of the video signal, thus acting like a network camera. If a device does allow broadcasting of the video, but does not record it, then it's called a [[video server]]. These devices effectively turn any analogue camera (or any analogue video signal) into a network TV.
=== Digital === [[Image:Trafikkamera.jpg|thumb|A traffic surveillance camera in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]]] These cameras do not require a video capture card because they work using a digital signal which can be saved directly to a computer. The signal is compressed 5:1, but [[DVD]] quality can be achieved with more compression (MPEG-2 is standard for DVD-video, and has a higher compression ratio than 5:1, with a slightly lower video quality than 5:1 at best, and is adjustable for the amount of space to be taken up versus the quality of picture needed or desired). The highest picture quality of DVD is only slightly lower than the quality of basic 5:1-compression DV.
Saving uncompressed digital recordings takes up an enormous amount of hard drive space, and a few hours of [[uncompressed video]] could quickly fill up a hard drive. Holiday uncompressed recordings may look fine but one could not run uncompressed quality recordings on a continuous basis. Motion detection is therefore sometimes used as a work around solution to record in uncompressed quality.
However, in any situation where standard-definition video cameras are used, the quality is going to be poor because the maximum [[pixel]] resolution of the image chips in most of these devices is 320,000 pixels (analogue quality is measured in TV lines but the results are the same); they generally capture horizontal and vertical fields of lines and blend them together to make a single frame; the maximum frame rate is normally 30 frames per second.
Nevertheless, multi-megapixel IP-CCTV cameras are coming on the market. Still quite expensive, but they can capture video images at resolutions of 1, 2, 3, 5 and even up to 11 Mpix. Unlike with analogue cameras, details such as number plates are easily readable. At 11 Mpix, forensic quality images are made where each hand on a person can be distinguished. Because of the much higher resolutions available with these types of cameras, they can be set up to cover a wide area where normally several analogue cameras would have been needed.
The worlds largest digital CCTV camera is a scaled up ST 205 CCTV camera unveiled by TelView on the 10th of July 2011. It measures 1.7 metres x 4.56m x 1.6m and has a sensitivity of 0.01 lux. <ref>{{Cite book|title=Guinness World Records 2016|last=Glenday|first=Craig|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-1-910561-01-0|location=|pages=115|quote=|via=}}</ref>
=== Network === [[Image:Elphel 333 board overside.png|thumb|Looking at the inside of a network camera. From left to right: network adapter, power supply, CPU, image encoder, image sensor.]]
[[IP camera]]s or network cameras are analogue or digital video cameras, plus an embedded [[video server]] having an [[IP address]], capable of streaming the video (and sometimes, even audio).
Because network cameras are embedded devices, and do not need to output an analogue signal, resolutions higher than [http://infronttech.com.au closed-circuit television] 'CCTV' analogue cameras are possible. A typical analogue CCTV camera has a [[PAL]] (768×576 [[pixel]]s) or [[NTSC]] (720×480 pixels), whereas network cameras may have [[VGA]] (640×480 pixels), SVGA (800×600 pixels) or quad-VGA (1280×960 pixels, also referred to as "megapixel") resolutions.
An analogue or digital camera connected to a video server acts as a network camera, but the image size is restricted to that of the video standard of the camera. However, optics (lenses and [[image sensor]]s), not video resolution, are the components that determine the image quality.
Network cameras can be used for very cheap surveillance solutions (requiring one network camera, some [[Ethernet]] cabling, and one PC), or to replace entire CCTV installations (cameras become network cameras, tape recorders become [[Digital video recorder|DVRs]], and CCTV [[video monitor|monitors]] become computers with [[TFT LCD|TFT]] screens and specialised software. Digital video manufacturers claim that turning CCTV installations into digital video installations is inherently better).
There continues to be much debate over the merits and price-for-performance of Network cameras as compared to analog cameras. Many in the CCTV industry claim that many analog cameras can outperform network cameras at a lower price.
<gallery> Image:Inside of an EverFocus CCTV camera 20110115.jpg|Looking at the inside of a CCTV camera Image:HitachiVKC150.jpg|Hitachi CCTV color camera Image:PhilipsCCTVlens.jpg|Philips CCTV Varifocal Auto-Iris security camera lens </gallery>
== Digital still cameras ==
The pixel resolution of the current models have easily reached 10 million pixels. Some point and shoot models like those produced by [[Canon Inc.|Canon]] or [[Nikon]] boast resolutions in excess of 20 million pixels. <ref>{{cite web|title=Nikon D5300|url=http://imaging.nikon.com/lineup/dslr/d5300/spec.htm}}</ref>
At these resolutions, and with high shutter speeds like 1/125th of a second, it is possible to take jpg pictures on a continuous or motion detection basis that will capture not only anyone running past the camera scene, but even the faces of those driving past.
These cameras can be plugged into the [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] port of any computer (most of them now have USB capability) and pictures can be taken of any camera scene. All that is necessary is for the camera to be mounted on a wall bracket and pointed in the desired direction.
Modern digital still cameras can take 500 kb snapshots in the space of 1 second, and these snapshots are then automatically downloaded by the camera software straight to the computer for storage as timed and dated [[JPEG]] files. The images themselves don't need to stay on the computer for long. If the computer is connected to the Internet, then the images can automatically be uploaded to any other computer anywhere in the world, as and when the pictures are taken.
The user does not need to lift a finger except to simply plug the camera in and point it in the desired direction. The direction could just as easily be the street outside a house, or the entrance to a bank or underground station.
Digital still cameras are now being made with in-built wireless connectivity, so that no USB cable is required; images are simply transmitted [[wireless]]ly through walls or ceilings to the computer.

{{Other uses|Countermeasure}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} In [[computer security]] a '''countermeasure''' is an action, [[peripheral|device]], [[Procedure (term)|procedure]], or technique that reduces a [[Threat (computer)|threat]], a [[Vulnerability (computing)|vulnerability]], or an [[attack (computing)|attack]] by eliminating or preventing it, by minimizing the [[harm]] it can cause, or by discovering and reporting it so that corrective action can be taken. The definition is as [[IETF]] RFC 2828RFC 2828 Internet Security Glossary that is the same as CNSS Instruction No. 4009 dated 26 April 2010 by [[Committee on National Security Systems]] of United States of America.[http://www.cnss.gov/Assets/pdf/cnssi_4009.pdf CNSS Instruction No. 4009] dated 26 April 2010 According to the Glossary[http://www.infosectoday.com/Articles/Glossary.pdf InfosecToday Glossary] by [http://www.infosectoday.com InfosecToday], the meaning of countermeasure is: :The deployment of a set of security services to protect against a security threat. A synonym is [[Security controls|security control]].{{cite book |last= Wright |first=Joe |authormask= |authorlink= |first2=Jim |last2=Harmening |editor-last=Vacca |editor-first=John |editor-link= |others= |title=Computer and Information Security Handbook |trans-title=|url= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series=Morgan Kaufmann Publications |volume= |date= |origyear= |year=2009 |month= |publisher= Elsevier Inc |location= |language= |isbn= 978-0-12-374354-1 |oclc= |doi= |bibcode= |id= |page=257 |pages= |nopp= |at= |chapter=15 |trans-chapter=|chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= }} In telecommunications, communication countermeasures are defined as [[Security service (telecommunication)|security services]] as part of [[OSI model|OSI Reference model]] by ITU-T X.800 Recommendation. X.800 and ISO ISO 7498-2 (Information processing systems – Open systems interconnection – Basic Reference Model – Part 2: Security architecture are technically aligned. The following picture explain the relationships between these concepts and terms: 
      + - - - - - - - - - - - - +  + - - - - +  + - - - - - - - - - - -+
      | An Attack:              |  |Counter- |  | A System Resource:   |
      | i.e., A Threat Action   |  | measure |  | Target of the Attack |
      | +----------+            |  |         |  | +-----------------+  |
      | | Attacker |<==================||<=========                 |  |
      | |   i.e.,  |   Passive  |  |         |  | |  Vulnerability  |  |
      | | A Threat |<=================>||<========>                 |  |
      | |  Agent   |  or Active |  |         |  | +-------|||-------+  |
      | +----------+   Attack   |  |         |  |         VVV          |
      |                         |  |         |  | Threat Consequences  |
      + - - - - - - - - - - - - +  + - - - - +  + - - - - - - - - - - -+
A resource (both physical or logical) can have one or more vulnerabilities that can be exploited by a threat agent in a threat action. The result can potentially compromises the [[confidentiality]], [[integrity]] or [[availability]] properties of resources (potentially different that the vulnerable one) of the organization and others involved parties (customers, suppliers).
The so-called CIA triad is the basis of [[information security]]. The attack can be active when it attempts to alter system resources or affect their operation: so it compromises integrity or availability. A "passive attack" attempts to learn or make use of information from the system but does not affect system resources, compromising confidentiality. A threat is a potential for violation of security, which exists when there is a circumstance, capability, action, or event that could breach security and cause harm. That is, a threat is a possible danger enabling the exploitation of a vulnerability. A threat can be either "intentional" (i.e., intelligent; e.g., an individual cracker or a criminal organization) or "accidental" (e.g., the possibility of a computer malfunctioning, or the possibility of an "act of God" such as an earthquake, a fire, or a tornado). A set of policies concerned with information security management, the [[information security management system]]s (ISMS), has been developed to manage, according to [[risk management]] principles, the countermeasures in order to accomplish to a security strategy set up following rules and regulations applicable in a country. == Countermeasures Against Physical Attacks == If a potential malicious actor has physical access to a computer system, they have a greater chance of inflicting harm upon it. === Electronic Destruction Devices === Devices such as a [[USB Killer]] may be used to damage or render completely unusable anything with a connection to the [[motherboard]] of a computer, such as a USB port, video port, Ethernet port, or serial port.{{Cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2016/12/usb-killer-fries-devices/|title=USB Killer, yours for $50, lets you easily fry almost every device|work=Ars Technica|access-date=2018-08-26|language=en-us}} Without proper protection, these devices may result in the destruction of ports, [[Expansion card|adapter cards]], storage devices, [[Random-access memory|RAM]], motherboards, CPUs, or anything physically connected to the device attacked, such as monitors, flash drives, or [[Network switch|wired switches]]. These types of devices can even be used to damage smartphones and cars, as well.{{Cite news|url=http://www.techfonder.com/2017/10/this-50-usb-killer-can-destroy-your-every-device-in-seconds.html|title=This $50 USB Killer Can Destroy Almost Any Smartphone, Computer Or Car Within Seconds|work=TechFonder|access-date=2018-08-26}} This threat can be mitigated by not installing or restricting physical access to easily accessible ports in situations where they are not necessary. A port-closing lock which permanently disables access to a port short of the actual port being disassembled.{{Cite web|url=https://www.mouser.com/blog/protect-usb-ports-from-nefarious-usb-killers|title=Bench Talk {{!}} Protect USB Ports From Nefarious “USB Killers"|website=www.mouser.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-26}} When it is necessary for a port to be accessible, an [[Opto-isolator|optocoupler]] can allow for a port to send and receive data to a computer or device without a direct electrical connection, preventing the computer or device from receiving any dangerous voltage from an external device.{{Cite web|url=https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/blog/optocoupler.html|title=Optocoupler Tutorial|last=|first=|date=|website=ElectronicsTutorials|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} === Hard Drives and Storage === In an unsecured scenario, a malicious actor may steal or destroy storage devices such as hard drives or SSDs, resulting in the destruction or theft of valuable data. If the data of a storage device is no longer necessary, data theft is best prevented against by physically destroying or shredding the storage device.{{Cite news|url=https://www.computerweekly.com/feature/Discarded-hard-drives-can-be-dangerous|title=Discarded hard drives can be dangerous|work=ComputerWeekly.com|access-date=2018-08-26|language=en-GB}} If the data of a storage device is in use and must be secured, one can use encryption to encrypt the contents of a storage device, or even [[Disk encryption#Full disk encryption|encrypt the whole storage device]] save for the master boot record. The device can then be unlocked with a password, [[biometric authentication]], a physical dongle, a network interchange, a [[one-time password]], or any combination thereof. If this device is a boot drive, however, it must be unencrypted in a pre-boot environment so the operating system can be accessed. [[Data striping|Striping]], or breaking data into chunks stored upon multiple drives which must be assemble in order to access the data, is a possible solution to physical drive theft, provided that the drives are stored in multiple, individually secured locations, and are enough in number that no one drive can be used to piece together meaningful information. Not the be neglected is the process of adding physical barriers to the storage devices themselves. Locked cases or physically hidden drives, with a limited amount of personnel with knowledge and access to the keys or locations, may prove to be a good first line against physical theft. == See also == {{Portal|Computer Security}} * [[Countermeasure]] * [[Computer security]] * [[Computer insecurity]] * [[Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures]] (CVE) * [[CVSS|Common Vulnerability Scoring System]] (CVSS) * [[Exploit (computer security)]] * [[Full disclosure (computer security)]] * [[IT risk]] * [[Metasploit]] * [[Month of Bugs]] * [[Vulnerability management]] * [[w3af]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://fismapedia.org/index.php?title=Term:Countermeasure Term in FISMApedia] {{DEFAULTSORT:Countermeasure (Computer)}} [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Computer network security]]

[[British Columbia Marijuana Party]] (2000–2003)
[[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democratic Party]] (2003–Present) | website = | footnotes = }} '''Dana Albert Larsen''' (born April 14, 1971) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] author, politician and [[cannabis rights]] activist. Larsen was the editor of ''[[Cannabis Culture (magazine)|Cannabis Culture]]'' magazine from its creation in 1994 until 2005, producing 54 issues with publisher [[Marc Emery]], who now also serves as editor.{{Cite news|title=The Constant of Change|magazine=Cannabis Culture Magazine|date=April 13, 2005|url=http://www.cannabisculture.com/articles/4276.html|accessdate=2008-01-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070612102727/http://www.cannabisculture.com/articles/4276.html|archivedate=June 12, 2007|df=}} Larsen was a founding member of both the [[Marijuana Party of Canada]] and the [[BC Marijuana Party]].{{Cite news|title= Pot Party Turns On To BC Election|newspaper=The Coast Independent|date=Jan 20, 2001|url=http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v01/n114/a08.html|accessdate=2008-01-15|postscript= }} In the [[Canadian federal election, 2000|2000 Canadian federal election]], Larsen ran as the Marijuana Party candidate for the riding of [[West Vancouver-Sunshine Coast]],{{Cite news|title= Marijuana Vote Lights Up|newspaper=North Shore News|date=November 13, 2000|url=http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v00/n1710/a03.html|accessdate=2008-01-15|postscript= }} receiving 3% of the vote.[[West Vancouver—Sunshine Coast—Sea to Sky Country]] In the [[British Columbia general election, 2001|2001 British Columbia provincial election]], Larsen ran as a BC Marijuana Party candidate in the [[Powell River-Sunshine Coast]] riding, receiving 3.5% of the vote.[[Powell River-Sunshine Coast]] After the 2001 election, Larsen became the Leader of the BC Marijuana Party.{{Cite news|title=Pot activists gear up for BC election|magazine=Cannabis Culture Magazine|date=February 4, 2005|url=http://www.cannabisculture.com/articles/4099.html|accessdate=2008-01-15|postscript=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606130023/http://www.cannabisculture.com/articles/4099.html|archivedate=June 6, 2011|df=}} In 2003, Larsen resigned from both Marijuana parties and joined the New Democratic Party.{{Cite news|title= Ex-Marijuana Party Leader Goes To NDP|newspaper=The Chief|date=December 12, 2003|url=http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n1914/a09.html|accessdate=2008-01-15|postscript= }}{{Cite news|title= Ex-Marijuana Party Leader To Run For NDP In Federal Election|newspaper=Whistler Question|date=December 11, 2003|url=http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n1907/a10.html|accessdate=2008-01-15|postscript= }} In 2005, Larsen founded a group called "End Prohibition, NDP Against the Drug War."{{cite web|title= End Prohibition, NDP Against the Drug War|url=http://www.endprohibition.ca|accessdate=2008-01-15}} Larsen has since claimed that End Prohibition has been instrumental in passing drug-policy [[Resolution (law)|resolutions]] through the provincial NDP in [[British Columbia]], [[Saskatchewan]] and [[Ontario]].{{cite web|title=BC NDP passes legalization resolution|date=2006-02-20|url=http://www.endprohibition.ca/2006_02_20_archive.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070123112132/http://www.endprohibition.ca/2006_02_20_archive.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-01-23|accessdate=2008-01-15|df=}}{{cite web|title=Sask NDP backs legal marijuana |date=2006-11-24 |url=http://www.endprohibition.ca/2006_11_24_archive.php |accessdate=2008-01-15 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070716112030/http://www.endprohibition.ca/2006_11_24_archive.php |archivedate=2007-07-16 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|title=ON NDP passes decrim resolution |date=2007-02-04 |url=http://www.endprohibition.ca/2007_02_04_archive.php |accessdate=2008-01-15 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070718023437/http://www.endprohibition.ca/2007_02_04_archive.php |archivedate=2007-07-18 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2006, Larsen co-founded the Vancouver Seed Bank,{{Cite news|title= Pot Activist Sells Seeds To Advance Cause|newspaper=The Vancouver Sun|date=September 15, 2006|url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=5aa55c7c-67f9-4718-b32a-fd4f16033ab8|accessdate=2015-06-10|format= – [https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=intitle%3APot+Activist+Sells+Seeds+To+Advance+Cause&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]|postscript= }}{{Cite news|title=New marijuana seed business sets up shop|newspaper=CBC.ca|date=September 14, 2006|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/new-marijuana-seed-business-sets-up-shop-1.590512|accessdate=2015-06-10|postscript=}} a business which sells many seed varieties from their storefront and also across Canada by mail-order, including those for banned and controversial psychoactive plants such as [[marijuana]], poppies, [[peyote]] and [[coca]].{{cite web|title= Welcome to the Vancouver Seed Bank |url=http://www.vancouverseedbank.ca/catalog/|accessdate=2008-01-15}} In 2007, Larsen released a book called ''Hairy Pothead and the Marijuana Stone'', a pot-laden [[Harry Potter parody]] published and distributed across North America by Cannabis Culture Magazine.{{cite web|title=Hairy Pothead and the Marijuana Stone in the media |url=http://www.HairyPothead.net/Main/INTHEMEDIA |accessdate=2008-01-15 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227091455/http://www.hairypothead.net/Main/INTHEMEDIA |archivedate=2007-12-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }} {{Cite news|title= B.C. bud inspires hemp-tinged parody of Harry Potter series|newspaper=The Vancouver Sun|date=September 21, 2007|url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/westcoastnews/story.html?id=140d0d0a-1932-4c70-acad-335dc34d03c7|accessdate=2015-06-10|format= – [https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=intitle%3AB.C.+bud+inspires+hemp-tinged+parody+of+Harry+Potter+series&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]|postscript= }} He is also the author of the Pot Puzzle Fun Book, released in 2000,{{cite web|title= Pot Puzzle Book Gets Good Reviews|url=http://www.cannabisculture.com/articles/1678.html|accessdate=2008-01-15}} the editor of Grow Like a Pro, a marijuana growing guide released in 2004,{{cite web|title= Grow Like a Pro|url=https://www.amazon.com/Grow-like-Pro-Marijuana-Advantage/dp/0932551602/|accessdate=2008-01-15}} and the creator of The Tokers Bowl Board Game.{{cite web|title=Tokers Bowl Board Game|url=http://www.cannabisculture.com/newstore/productpage.cgi?num=111|accessdate=2008-01-15}} In 2008, he was the federal [[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democratic Party]] candidate for the riding of [[West Vancouver—Sunshine Coast—Sea to Sky Country]] for the 2008 election, however, he resigned on September 17, after videos he had filmed for Pot-TV in 1999 were released to the media, which showed him taking LSD and smoking marijuana.{{Cite news|title= Pot Activist Is NDP Candidate In Next Federal Election |newspaper=Pique Newsmagazine |date=May 17, 2007|url=http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v07/n623/a02.html|accessdate=2008-01-15|postscript= }}{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canadavotes/story/2008/09/17/ndp-larsen.html | work=CBC News | title=B.C. New Democrat's candidacy up in smoke | date=2008-09-18}} In November 2008, Larsen announced the opening of the Vancouver Medicinal [[Cannabis Dispensary]], located almost next door to the Vancouver Seed Bank. The [[cannabis dispensary]] is operated by a non-profit society of which Larsen is a Director.{{Cite web |title=About the Vancouver Dispensary Society |url=http://www.cannabisdispensary.ca/Main/about |accessdate=2008-11-07 |postscript= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204042248/http://cannabisdispensary.ca/Main/about |archivedate=February 4, 2009 |df= }}{{Cite news|title= New Venture |newspaper=24 Hours Vancouver|date=November 7, 2008|url=http://vancouver.24hrs.ca/News/2008/11/07/7333996-sun.html|accessdate=2008-11-07|postscript= }} In July 2010, the [[cannabis dispensary]] opened a second location, located in Vancouver's West End.https://theprovince.com/life/Medical+marijuana+dispensary+opens+Vancouver+West/3066062/story.html Larsen also serves as a Director of The Always Growing Green Society, which in May 2010 opened the TAGGS medicinal [[cannabis dispensary]] in Maple Ridge, BC.http://www.bclocalnews.com/tri_city_maple_ridge/mapleridgenews/news/98371229.htmlhttp://whyprohibition.ca/blogs/jacob-hunter/maple-ridge-dispensary-marks-7th-medical-marijuana-outlet-british-columbiahttp://www.taggsdispensary.ca/about.html On December 29, 2010, Larsen announced his candidacy for the [[British Columbia New Democratic Party leadership election, 2011|leadership]] of the [[British Columbia NDP]].{{cite web|url=https://vancouversun.com/news/activist+Dana+Larsen+announce+leadership+plans/4034351/story.html#ixzz19VoJdrHx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428192026/http://www.vancouversun.com/news/activist+Dana+Larsen+announce+leadership+plans/4034351/story.html |archivedate=2011-04-28 |df= }}.[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/pot-activist-kicks-off-b-c-ndp-leadership-race-1.953798 "Pot activist kicks off B.C. NDP leadership race]", ''CBC News'', December 29, 2010https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yB_oHSF1-CI He came in fourth with 2.7% of the vote.[[British Columbia New Democratic Party leadership election, 2011#Dana Larsen]] In September 2012, Larsen launched the Sensible BC campaign to decriminalize cannabis possession in BC through a referendum.{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2012/09/20/bc-pot-petition-larsen.html | work=CBC News}}https://vancouversun.com/news/Marijuana+activist+Dana+Larsen+launches+petition/7274669/story.html The campaign had 4000 volunteers gather 202,085 signatures in 90 days, from September 9 to December 9, 2013.[http://sensiblebc.ca/campaign-final-report-from-dana-larsen/ "How did we do?"] Although not enough to qualify for a referendum, it was the second-highest total ever gathered for a BC referendum effort.[http://www.elections.bc.ca/docs/init/Summary-Initiatives-1995-2013.pdf "Summary of Initiative Petitions"] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Larsen, Dana}} [[Category:Articles with inconsistent citation formats]] [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British Columbia candidates for Member of Parliament]] [[Category:British Columbia Marijuana Party politicians]] [[Category:Canadian humorists]] [[Category:Canadian cannabis activists]] [[Category:Canadian magazine editors]] [[Category:Canadian people of Norwegian descent]] [[Category:Candidates in British Columbia provincial elections]] [[Category:Cannabis political party politicians]] [[Category:Marijuana Party of Canada candidates for the Canadian House of Commons]] [[Category:New Democratic Party candidates for the Canadian House of Commons]] [[Category:Politicians from Vancouver]] [[Category:Psychedelic drug advocates]] [[Category:Writers from Vancouver]]
