(weekend of 21 April 2019) }} {| class="infobox" |{{football kit | pattern_la = _red_stripes | pattern_b = _whitestripes3 | pattern_ra = _red_stripes | pattern_sh = | pattern_so = | leftarm = FFFFFF | body = FF0000 | rightarm = FFFFFF | shorts = 000000 | socks = 000000 | title = Athletic Bilbao }} |{{football kit | pattern_la = _shoulder_stripes_white_shirt_alt | pattern_b = _shoulder_stripes_white_shirt | pattern_ra = _shoulder_stripes_white_shirt_alt | pattern_so = _color_3_stripes_on_white | pattern_sh = _adidasonwhite | leftarm = 632CF7 | body = 632CF7 | rightarm = 632CF7 | shorts = 632CF7 | socks = 632CF7 | title = Real Madrid }} |} '''El Viejo Clásico''' (''The Old Classic'') also known as ''El Otro Clásico'' (''The Other Classic'') is the name given to any [[Association football|football]] match between [[Athletic Bilbao]] and [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rtve.es/deportes/20130414/viejo-clasico-espanol-athletic-madrid-se-despide-san-mames/639163.shtml|publisher=[[RTVE]]|date=14 April 2013|accessdate=13 November 2017|title=El viejo Clásico español, Athletic–Madrid, se despide de San Mamés|trans-title=The 'old classic' of Spain, Athletic–Madrid, says goodbye to San Mamés|language=es}} Until 10 December 2011, this fixture was the most played in the history of [[Football in Spain|Spanish football]], when it was surpassed by [[El Clásico]].{{cite web|url=https://as.com/futbol/2011/12/10/mas_futbol/1323502015_850215.html|publisher=[[Diario AS]]|date=10 December 2011|accessdate=13 November 2017|language=es|title=El Clásico de los Clásicos: 216 partidos oficiales|trans-title=The classic of all classics: 216 official matches}} However, it remains the most played game in the [[Copa del Rey]]. These two clubs and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] are the only three teams to have participated in all editions of [[La Liga]], the national league championship.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/clubs/club=31071/index.html |title=Classic club: Athletic Bilbao |publisher=[[FIFA]] |accessdate=17 November 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906093039/https://web.archive.org/web/20110915111333/http://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/clubs/club=31071/index.html |archive-date= 6 September 2011 |df=dmy }} Both are owned by their ''socios'' (members) who elect a club president to oversee its affairs.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/8076515.stm|title=Perez to return as Real president |date=1 June 2009|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 November 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/elecciones-2015/noticias/201503/08/urrutia-unico-candidato-presidencia-20150308153104.html|title=Urrutia será proclamado presidente el próximo 20 de marzo|trans-title=Urrutia to be proclaimed president the next 20 March|publisher=[[El Correo]]|language=Spanish|date=8 March 2015|accessdate=15 November 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/football/how-real-madrid-club-socios-president-elections-structure-functions|title=Behind the scenes at Real Madrid: How the club is structured and how it functions|date=3 August 2015|access-date=15 November 2017}} ==History== Their first meeting occurred in the [[1903 Copa del Rey Final|final]] of the first edition of the [[Copa del Rey]], played on 8 April 1903; Athletic won 3–2.[http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/match-statistics/1_2356/1902-03_athletic-club_real-madrid-cf.html Athletic-Real Madrid Final 1903 Cup] That match has been identified as a catalyst for the establishment a few weeks later of what would eventually become [[Club Atlético de Madrid]], after some Madrid-based Basque students among the spectators were inspired by the comeback victory by Athletic Bilbao and decided to form a local branch of the club.{{cite web|title=More Than A Game: Atletico Madrid vs Real Madrid|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/more-game-atletico-madrid-vs-real-madrid|date=1 January 2006|publisher=[[FourFourTwo]] |accessdate=5 June 2018}} Their first match at the original [[San Mamés Stadium (1913)|San Mamés]] took place in that competition in [[1920 Copa del Rey|1920]].{{cite web|title=Los Athletic-Real Madrid están a punto de cumplir 97 años|trans-title=Athletic v Real Madrid is reaching the point of 97 years|url=https://as.com/futbol/2017/03/18/primera/1489805309_593835.html|language=Spanish|date=18 March 2017|work=Diario AS|accessdate=13 November 2017}} Meetings became common as Athletic Bilbao and Real Madrid dominated the regional tournaments ([[Biscay Championship]] and [[Campeonato Regional Centro|Madrid Regional Championship]] respectively), the winning of which granted access to the Copa del Rey. The [[Basques]] and [[Castilians]] met in nine Cup finals between 1903 and 1958; Athletic won six of these matches.{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/past-seasons.html|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=|accessdate=13 November 2017|title=Past seasons (filter: versus Real Madrid, Cup)}}{{cite web|url=http://inbedwithmaradona.com/retro/2012/7/4/the-history-of-athletic-bilbao-1898-1936.html|last=Radnedge|first=Keir|title=The history of Athletic Bilbao 1898–1936|magazine=[[World Soccer (magazine)|World Soccer]] (via ''In Bed With Maradona'' website)|date=1 August 1977|accessdate=21 November 2017}} ===First league matches, Francoist Spain and beyond=== On 21 April 1929, Athletic Bilbao and Real Madrid met for the first time in La Liga; Real Madrid won the match at [[Estadio Chamartín|Chamartín]] 5–1.[http://www.bdfutbol.com/en/p/p.php?id=45 Real Madrid 5–1 Athletic Bilbao at BDFútbol] The 1929 Copa del Rey semi-final second leg in Bilbao became known as the 'frog match', after a local company distributed toys which made frog-like noises to increase the noise level in the stadium to distract the visitors, who were 3–1 up from the first leg. The ploy failed resoundingly, with Real Madrid recording a 4–1 win to progress 7–2; however they would lose the final. The two clubs would share ten of the [[List of Spanish football champions|first 25 championships]] (Athletic six, Madrid four) either side of the [[Spanish Civil War]] up to 1956, but from that point ''Los Blancos'' became [[History of Real Madrid C.F.#Santiago Bernabéu Yeste|the dominant club in the country]], winning 16 titles from 26 available (plus six [[European Cup]]s). [[File:Cristiano (4590945149).jpg|thumb|left|210px|Real Madrid's [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] (left) and Athletic Bilbao's [[Ander Iturraspe]] during a match at [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium]], 2010]] In that era, the ''[[caudillo]]'' [[General Franco]] used the success of the club (based in the [[Madrid|capital city]], the seat of power) as a vehicle to promote [[Francoist Spain]] to foreigners,{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/franco-real-madrid-and-spanish-football-s-eternal-power-struggle-1-2564913|last=Fitzpatrick|first=Richard |title=Franco, Real Madrid and Spanish football’s eternal power struggle|work=The Scotsman|date=7 October 2012|accessdate=16 November 2017}} whereas Athletic Bilbao – the largest club in the peripheral [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque region]]{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/mar/26/newsstory.sport13|title=Morbo: The Story of Spanish Football by Phil Ball (London: WSC Books, 2001)|date=26 March 2001|accessdate=16 November 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|last=[[Sid Lowe|Lowe]]|first=Sid}}{{cite web|author=Fox Sports |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/athletic-bilbao-club-all-basque-policy-spain-manchester-united-contrast-030812-2-030812 |title=Athletic Bilbao: Pride or prejudice |publisher=FOX Sports |date=2012-03-08 |accessdate=16 November 2017}}{{cite web|author=Neil Stacey |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/copa90/2016/jan/15/athletic-club-bilbao-loyalty-spain-liga-basque |title=This is Athletic Bilbao: the club whose loyalty to local talent is not negotiable |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=16 November 2017}}{{cite web|author=Pete Jenson |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/pete-jenson-athletic-bilbao-s-locals-only-transfer-policy-shows-success-does-not-need-to-be-bought-9692663.html |title=Pete Jenson: Athletic Bilbao's locals-only transfer policy shows success does not need to be bought |publisher=The Independent |date=2014-08-26 |accessdate=16 November 2017}} whose customs and language were repressed by the central government – won no titles in the same period, only even finishing runners-up once. The Basques and other regions [[Spanish transition to democracy|regained more self-control]] in the years following Franco's death in 1975, symbolised by the joint display of the banned [[Ikurriña|Basque flag]] by the captains of Athletic and [[Basque derby|local rivals]] [[Real Sociedad]] at a match between them a year later.{{cite web|url=http://www.canalathletic.com/noticias/2010-12-03/aquel-historico-diciembre-1976-20101203.html|title=Aquel histórico 5 de diciembre de 1976|trans-title=That historic 5 December 1976|work=[[El Correo]]|language=Spanish|date=3 December 2010|accessdate=16 November 2017}} However, many of the supporters of Athletic and Real Madrid, including their [[Ultras]] groups (''[[:es:Herri Norte Taldea|Herri Norte]]'' and ''[[:es:Ultras Sur|Ultras Sur]]'' respectively), still adhere to opposing views in terms of their [[Nationalities and regions of Spain|national identity]].{{cite news |title = Real Madrid moves to send off Ultras Sur fans | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/09/real-madrid-ultras-sur-fans | work = The Guardian | location = London | first = Ashifa | last = Kassam | accessdate =16 November 2017 | date=9 December 2013}}{{cite web|first=Javier|last=Sánchez|title=La geografía de la violencia|trans-title=The geography of violence|url=http://www.elmundo.es/deportes/2014/12/01/547c7ac8268e3e20718b4575.html|language=Spanish|date=1 December 2014|work=El Mundo|accessdate=13 November 2017}}{{cite web|title=El mapa ultra de España|trans-title=The ultras map of Spain |url=http://deportes.elpais.com/deportes/2014/12/06/actualidad/1417883083_251007.html|language=Spanish|date=6 December 2014|work=[[El País]]|accessdate=13 November 2017}} In this regard, the relationship has similarities with the more famous and intense ''El Clásico'' rivalry between Real Madrid and Barcelona (representing [[Catalonia]]).{{cite news|last=[[Phil Ball (writer)|Ball]] | first=Phil |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/apr/21/championsleague.sport |title=The ancient rivalry of Barcelona and Real Madrid |work=The Guardian |date= 21 April 2002 |accessdate=16 November 2017 | location=London}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2017/oct/02/barcelona-in-strange-and-symbolic-eye-of-a-storm-over-catalonia|title=Barcelona in the strange and symbolic eye of a storm over Catalonia |newspaper=The Guardian|date=2 October 2017|accessdate=9 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2010/jan/18/real-madrid-gorka-iraizoz-athletic|title=Real Madrid repelled as Gorka Iraizoz emulates the Squid |work=The Guardian|date=18 January 2010|accessdate=16 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/game-politics-football-interplay-spain-180403172920861.html|title=More than a game: How politics and football interplay in Spain|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|author=David Child|date=18 April 2018|accessdate=11 June 2018}} On the field, a competitive edge was briefly restored in the early 1980s when Athletic built a strong combative team that [[History of Athletic Bilbao#The Clemente years|won the league twice]], finishing ahead of Real Madrid by one point in [[1982–83 La Liga|1983]] with the top spot changing hands on the last day;{{cite web|url=http://footballrepublik.com/la-liga-seasons-athletic-bilbao-conquer-spain-198283/|title=La Liga seasons: Athletic Bilbao’s Basque Glory – 1982/83|work=Football Republik|date=24 August 2013|accessdate=21 November 2017}} the season was nothing short of a disaster for the ''Meringues'', who also lost in the finals of the [[1982 Supercopa de España|Supercopa]], the [[1983 Copa del Rey Final|Copa del Rey]] (to a last-minute goal), the [[1983 European Cup Winners' Cup Final|European Cup Winners' Cup]] (in extra time), and the [[1983 Copa de la Liga|Copa de la Liga]]. In the following campaign, Athletic pipped Madrid by a single goal and better head-to-head record,{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/real-madrid/2017/05/22/5922e820ca4741256a8b462d.html|title=The Real Madrid of La Quinta|work=Marca|date=22 May 2017|accessdate=21 November 2017}} but their [[1983–84 La Liga|league]] and [[1983–84 Copa del Rey|cup]] double that year was the last time they lifted either trophy; Real Madrid soon responded with a run of five-in-a-row, led by their group of homegrown talent, [[La Quinta del Buitre]]. During a hotly-contested fixture in Bilbao in March 1990, the referee awarded a dubious penalty to the away side and had to halt the game for 12 minutes after objects were thrown at the [[Assistant referee (association football)|linesman]] and Madrid goalkeeper [[Francisco Buyo|Paco Buyo]].{{cite web|url=https://elpais.com/diario/1990/03/18/deportes/637714806_850215.html|title=La fuerza del Athlétic devaluó el arte del Madrid|trans-title=Athletic's force cancels out Madrid's art|language=Spanish|newspaper=El País|date=18 March 1990|accessdate=21 November 2017}} The match finished as normal, but as a consequence the San Mamés stadium was closed for one match, with Athletic playing [[Real Valladolid]] at the [[Atotxa Stadium]] in [[San Sebastián]].{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/match-statistics/1_1713/1989-90_athletic-club_real-valladolid.html|title=Athletic Club 2–2 Real Valladolid|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=|accessdate=21 Atocha|language=Spanish|newspaper=El País|date=27 March 1990|accessdate=21 November 2017}} ===21st century=== [[File:Athmadrid.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Kaká]] scoring a penalty at the [[San Mamés Stadium (1913)|old San Mamés]] in 2011]] Entering the 21st century, other clubs offered significant challenges to Real Madrid, such as [[Atlético Madrid]] (their [[Madrid Derby|city rivals]] who were originally formed as an offshoot of Athletic Bilbao and thus have a similar name, crest and kit),{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/clubs/club=31070/index.html |title=Classic club: Atlético Madrid |publisher=[[FIFA]] |accessdate=17 November 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906093039/http://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/clubs/club%3D31070/index.html |archive-date=6 September 2011 |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/why-everything-you-know-about-madrid-derby-might-be-wrong|title=Think Real Madrid vs Atletico Madrid is all about Franco's elite vs the honest poor? Not really, as Richard Ballout explains... |work=FourFourTwo|date=7 January 2015|accessdate=16 November 2017}} [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] and Barcelona. Athletic Bilbao were not among this group, now hampered by their self-imposed [[Athletic Bilbao signing policy|restrictive Basque-only player policy]] in an age of worldwide recruitment, exemplified by Madrid's ''[[Galácticos]]'' who won seven further [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]]s between 1998 and 2018. Real Madrid have a [[Real Madrid C.F.#Support|global fanbase]] and are one of the world's richest,{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2013/07/15/real-madrid-tops-the-worlds-most-valuable-sports-teams/| title=Real Madrid Tops The World's Most Valuable Sports Teams |date=15 July 2013 |accessdate=16 November 2017 |agency=Forbes| first=Kurt | last=Badenhausen}} [[List of Real Madrid C.F. honours|most decorated]]{{cite web|title = World Football: The 11 Most Successful European Clubs in History | url = http://bleacherreport.com/articles/510011-world-football-the-11-most-successful-european-clubs-in-history/page/12 | accessdate =16 November 2017}} and best-attended{{cite web|url=http://www.european-football-statistics.co.uk/attn.htm|title=Attendances (Filter: Europe)|website=European Football Statistics|date=|accessdate=16 November 2017}} clubs. Athletic have a much lower profile and have occasionally flirted with relegation,{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/dec/04/europeanfootball.sport1|title=Are Bilbao about to bow out? |work=[[The Guardian]]|date=4 December 2006|accessdate=11 June 2018}} although they have consistently ranked among the top half-dozen clubs in Spain for performance,{{cite web|url=http://www.european-football-statistics.co.uk/league.htm|title=Domestic League Rankings (Filters: Spain, Table of Last 25 seasons)|website=European Football Statistics|date=|accessdate=16 November 2017}} matchday attendance and popularity.{{cite web|url=http://www.as.com/futbol/articulo/espana-pasa-madrid-barcelona/20111010dasdaiftb_3/Tes |title=España se pasa del Madrid al fought due to their historical and cultural significance.{{cite web|url=https://syndication.bleacherreport.com/amp/1940809-athletic-bilbao-vs-real-madrid-a-tale-of-two-transfer-policies.amp.html|title=Athletic Bilbao vs. Real Madrid: A Tale of 2 Transfer Policies |website=Bleacher Report|date=31 January 2014|accessdate=11 December 2017}} There is no doubt who has the upper hand in recent meetings: in [[2004–05 La Liga|2004–05]] Athletic won home and away against Real Madrid, but since then they won just two of their home matches{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31773433|title=Athletic Bilbao 1–0 Real Madrid|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=7 March 2015|accessdate=16 November 2017}} in the dozen seasons up to [[2016–17 La Liga|2016–17]], and took no points at all from the 12 matches at the [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium|Bernabéu]]{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/amp/football/news/11095/11337176/real-madrid-1-1-athletic-bilbao-late-cristiano-ronaldo-flick-denies-bilbao-historic-win|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=18 April ''Merengues'' also won both legs of the most recent cup tie between the sides in [[2005–06 Copa del Rey|2006]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2006-01/13/content_511926.htm|title=Real overpower sorry Bilbao with 4–0 Cup win|work=China Daily|date=13 January 2006|accessdate=16 November 2017}} In April 2011, Real Madrid registered a 3–0 away win over Athletic despite resting several players for important upcoming games,{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/amp/match/athletic-club-vs-real-madrid/980757/report|title=Athletic Bilbao 0–3 Real Madrid: Kaka & Cristiano Ronaldo ease Los Blancos past Basques ahead of next week's web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/la-liga/9242655/Real-Madrid-clinch-32nd-La-Liga-title-as-Cristiano-Ronaldo-rounds-off-3-0-win-against-Athletic-Bilbao.html|title=Real The '''European Climate Exchange''' (ECX) managed the product development and marketing for ECX Carbon Financial Instruments (ECX CFIs), listed and admitted for trading on the ICE Futures Europe [[Commodities exchange|electronic platform]]. For a time it was a subsidiary of the [[Chicago Climate Exchange]] but eventually became a sister company. Both companies were owned by Climate Exchange Plc a [[holding company]] listed on the [[London Stock Exchange]]'s [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM]] market. While products are listed on the London Stock Exchange, the sales and marketing team was initially based in Amsterdam, the Netherlands under its first CEO, [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=22803668&privcapId=39666402 Peter Koster], before moving to London, UK in October 2007.
ECX financial products, now fully owned by ICE Futures, provide the most liquid, pan-European platform for [[carbon emissions trading]], with its [[futures contract]] based on the underlying [[European Union Greenhouse Gas Emission Trading Scheme#Allocation|EU Allowance]]s (EUAs) and Certified Emissions Allowances (CERs) attracting over 80% of the exchange-traded volume in the European market. ECX contracts (EUA and CER Futures, options and [[spot contract]]s) are standardised exchange-traded products and all trades are cleared by ICE Clear Europe<ref>[https://www.theice.com/clear_europe.jhtml "Ice Clear Europe"], [[Intercontinental Exchange]], retrieved 26 July 2010</ref> ([[LCH.Clearnet]] was the designated clearing house prior to November 2008).
More than 100 leading businesses, including global companies such as [[Barclays]], [[BP]], [[Newedge]], E.ON UK, Endesa, Fortis, [[Goldman Sachs]], [[Morgan Stanley]] and [[Shell (company)|Shell]] have signed up for membership to trade ECX products. In addition, several hundred clients can access the market daily via banks and brokers in a process called 'order-routing' without having to be a member themselves.
ECX was a member of the Climate Exchange Plc group of companies, founded by [[Richard Sandor]]. Other member companies include the Chicago Climate Exchange (“CCX”) and IFEX. Climate Exchange Plc is listed on AIM (Alternative Investment Market) on the London Stock Exchange, and was bought in April 2010 by [[Intercontinental Exchange]] (ICE).<ref>http://www.climateexchangeplc.com/investor-relations/recommended-cash-acquisition-by-aether-ios-limited-of-climate-exchange-plc</ref><ref>http://www.climateexchangeplc.com/</ref>
The last Chief Executive was [[Patrick Birley]], son of archaeologist [[Robin Birley (archaeologist)|Robin Birley]].<ref>[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/markets/europe/article2697778.ece Traders with a permit to save the planet]</ref><ref>[http://www.birley.org/jbirleyd/d152.htm#P152 Patrick Burley at www.birley.org] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050223163931/http://www.birley.org/jbirleyd/d152.htm#P152 |date=February 23, 2005 }}</ref>
==Protests== On 1 April 2009, [[Camp for Climate Action]] protesters set up a campsite and farmers' market outside the European Climate Exchange in Hasilwood House in Bishopsgate, City of London, to protest against [[carbon emission trading|carbon trading]] as a "false solution" to the problem of [[climate change]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/climate-change-protesters-set-up-camp-in-bishopsgate-1659508.html| title= The Independent - Climate Change Protesters Set Up Camp in Bishopsgate | location=London | first=Emily | last=Beament | date=1 April 2009 | accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref><ref>http://climatecamp.org.uk</ref>
On 23 July 2010, European Climate Exchange's [[website]] was targeted by [[Hactivism|hacktivists]] operating under the name of [[Decocidio|decocidio #ϴ]]. The website showed a [[parody|spoof]] [[homepage]] for around 22 hours in an effort to promote the contention that [[carbon emission trading|carbon trading]] is a false solution to the [[Global warming|climate crisis]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/jul/26/eu-carbon-trading-website-hacked| title= Hackers shut down EU carbon-trading website| work= [[The Guardian]]| date= 26 July 2010| first= Leigh |last=Phillips}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|energy}} * [[Carbon credit]] * [[Chicago Climate Exchange]] * [[Emissions trading]] * [[List of renewable resources produced and traded by the United Kingdom]] * [[Kyoto Protocol]] * [[List of futures exchanges]] * [[Mobile Emission Reduction Credit (MERC)]]

'''Fairshare''' Voting Reform is a cross-party and non-party organisation set up in February 2001 to campaign for the introduction of the [[Single Transferable Vote]] system of [[Proportional Representation]] (STV-PR) for local government elections in [[Scotland]]. In January 2005 Fairshare extended its objectives to promote reform of the voting systems used for all public elections in [[Scotland]] and, specifically, to reform the voting system for elections to the [[Scottish Parliament]] through the adoption of STV-PR. The campaign maintains a network of Registered Supporters.
Fairshare was constituted as a not-for-profit company limited by guarantee (SC216224) when it employed staff and rented office premises, but the company was dissolved in June 2012 to minimise costs.

'''Family Fund''' is a [[UK]] based registered [[Charitable organization|charity]] for [[disabled]] children and their [[families]]. The Chief Executive of this charity is Cheryl Ward.
Formed in 1973 by the UK Government to give practical help to families with severely disabled and seriously ill children under the age of 18. For over 20 years the Family Fund operated under the wing of the [[Joseph Rowntree Foundation]] but in 1996 became an independent charity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jrf.org.uk/about-us/faq/jrf-connected-family-fund |title=Is the JRF connected to the Family Fund? |work=Joseph Rowntree Foundation website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927120238/http://www.jrf.org.uk/about-us/faq/jrf-connected-family-fund |archivedate=2011-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
The charity aims to help families with disabled or seriously ill children and young people aged 17 and under to have choices and the opportunity to enjoy ordinary life by giving grants to families on the lowest of incomes to help relieve the stress of everyday life.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/DG_10011132 |title=Family Fund page at Directgov |work=Directgov website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927033642/http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/DG_10011132 |archivedate=2012-09-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhs.uk/CarersDirect/guide/practicalsupport/Pages/FamilyFund.aspx|title=Family Fund page at NHS|work=NHS website}}</ref>
The charity operates under its own definition of [http://www.familyfund.org.uk/page.asp?section=00010001000100050005&sectionTitle=Family+Fund+definition+of+severe+disability severe disability] and [http://www.familyfund.org.uk/page.asp?section=00010001000100050007&sectionTitle=Household+income income criteria]. The charity aims to help eligible families once every year with [[grants]] for things that make life easier and more enjoyable for the disabled child, young person and their family - items such as white goods, outdoor play equipment, computers and holidays.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/index/contacts/contacts-az.htm/family-fund |title=Family Fund page at NI Direct |work=NI Direct Government Services website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101221155302/http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/index/contacts/contacts-az.htm/family-fund |archivedate=2010-12-21 |df= }}</ref>
The national governments of England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales provide grants to the charity, as part of their commitment to disabled children and young people. The charity is the UK's largest grant giving organisation and currently helps around 66,000 families in the UK with around £33 million in grants a year.

[[File:Presence of Albanians in "Greater Albania".png|200px|thumb|Albanians in Albania and neighboring countries]] '''Greater Albania'''<ref>http://www.da.mod.uk/colleges/csrc/document-listings/balkan/07%2811%29MD.pdf,"as {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180510022534/https://www.da.mod.uk/colleges/csrc/document-listings/balkan/07(11)MD.pdf, |date=10 May 2018 }} Albanians continue mobilizing their ethnic presence in a cultural, geographic and economic sense, they further the process of creating a Greater Albania. "</ref> is an [[irredentist]] concept of lands that are considered to form the national homeland by many Albanians,<ref>{{cite news|last=Likmeta|first=Besar|title=Poll Reveals Support for 'Greater Albania'|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/survey-greater-albania-remains-popular|accessdate=27 June 2013|date=17 November 2010|agency=[[Balkan Insight]]|quote=The poll, conducted by Gallup in cooperation with the European Fund for the Balkans, showed that 62 per cent of respondents in Albania, 81 per cent in Kosovo and 51.9 per cent of respondents in Macedonia supported the formation of a Greater Albania.}}</ref> based on claims on the present-day or historical presence of Albanian populations in those areas. In addition to the existing [[Republic of Albania]], the term incorporates claims to regions in the neighbouring states, the areas include [[Kosovo]] and the [[Preševo Valley]] of [[Serbia]], territories in southern [[Montenegro]], northwestern [[Greece]] (the Greek regional units of [[Thesprotia]] and [[Preveza]], referred by Albanians as [[Chameria]], and other territories that were part of the [[Vilayet of Yanina]] during the Ottoman Empire),<ref name="Merdjanova147"/><ref name="Kola15">{{harvnb|Kola|2003|p=15}}.</ref><ref name="Seton-Watson189"/><ref name="Austin237"/><ref name="Vaknin102103"/> and a part of western [[Republic of Macedonia]].
The unification of an even larger area into a unique territory under Albanian authority had been theoretically conceived by the [[League of Prizren]], an organization of the 19th century whose goal was to unify the Albanian inhabited lands (and other regions, mostly from the region of Macedonia, Epirus and Montenegro) into a single autonomous [[Albanian Vilayet]] within the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref name="Jelavich361365">{{harvnb|Jelavich|1983|pp=361–365}}.</ref> However, the concept of a Greater Albania, as in greater than Albania within its 1913 borders, was implemented only under the [[Albanian under Italy|Italian]] and [[Albania under Nazi Germany|Nazi German]] occupation of the [[Balkans]] during [[World War II]].<ref name="Zolo24"/> The idea of unification, has roots in the events of the [[Treaty of London (1913)|Treaty of London]] in 1913, when roughly half of the predominantly Albanian territories and 40% of the population were left outside the new country's borders,<ref name="Bugajski675">{{harvnb|Bugajski|2002|p=675}}."Roughly half of the predominantly Albanian territories and 40% of the population were left outside the new country's borders"</ref> something that Albanians have tended to regard as an injustice imposed by the Great Powers.
According to the ''Gallup Balkan Monitor'' 2010 report, the idea of a Greater Albania is supported by the majority of Albanians in Albania (63%), Kosovo (81%) and the Republic of Macedonia (53%), although the same report noted that most Albanians thought this unlikely to happen.<ref>[http://www.balkan-monitor.eu/files/BalkanMonitor-2010_Summary_of_Findings.pdf Gallup Balkan Monitor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121227084847/http://www.balkan-monitor.eu/files/BalkanMonitor-2010_Summary_of_Findings.pdf |date=27 December 2012 }}, 2010</ref><ref>Balkan Insight ''Poll Reveals Support for 'Greater Albania' '', 17 Nov 2010 [http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/survey-greater-albania-remains-popular]</ref>
In a survey carried out by [[United Nations Development Programme]] (UNDP), published in March 2007, only 2.5% of the Albanians in Kosovo thought unification with Albania is the best solution for Kosovo. Ninety-six percent said they wanted Kosovo to become independent within its present borders.<ref>UNDP: Early Warning Report. March 2007, p. 16 ([http://www.kosovo.undp.org/repository/docs/EWR15FinalENG.pdf Online text)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518102355/http://www.kosovo.undp.org/repository/docs/EWR15FinalENG.pdf |date=18 May 2015 }}</ref>
==Terminology== '''Greater Albania''' is a term used mainly by the Western scholars, politicians, etc.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} Albanian nationalists dislike the expression "Greater Albania" and prefer to use the term "Ethnic Albania".<ref name="Judah120"/> '''Ethnic Albania''' ({{lang-sq|Shqipëria Etnike}}) is a term used primarily by [[Albanian nationalism|Albanian nationalists]] to denote the territories claimed as the traditional homeland of ethnic Albanians, despite these lands also being inhabited by many non-Albanians.<ref name="BogdaniLoughlin230"/> Those that use the second term refer to an area which is smaller than the four Ottoman vilayets, while still encompassing Albania, Kosovo, western Macedonia, Albanian populated areas of Southern Serbia and parts of Northern Greece ([[Chameria]]) that had a historic native Albanian population.<ref name="Judah120"/> Albanian nationalists ignore that within these regions there are also sizable numbers of non-Albanians.<ref name="Judah120">{{harvnb|Judah|2008|p=120}}.</ref> Another term used by Albanians, is "Albanian national reunification" ({{lang-sq|Ribashkimi kombëtar shqiptar}}).<ref>{{cite news|title=Alternativat e ribashkimit kombëtar të shqiptarëve dhe të Shqipërisë Etnike..!|url=http://gazetaditore.com/2012/12/10/alternativat-e-ribashkimit-kombetar-te-shqiptareve-dhe-te-shqiperise-etnike/|accessdate=1 January 2013|newspaper=Gazeta Ditore|date=10 December 2012|language=Albanian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130124112221/http://gazetaditore.com/2012/12/10/alternativat-e-ribashkimit-kombetar-te-shqiptareve-dhe-te-shqiperise-etnike/|archivedate=24 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==History==
===Under the Ottoman Empire=== [[File:Albanian vilayet.jpg|thumb|right|The four Ottoman vilayets ([[Kosovo Vilayet|Kosovo]], [[Scutari Vilayet|Scutari]], [[Monastir Vilayet|Monastir]] and [[Janina Vilayet|Janina]]), proposed as [[Albanian vilayet]], by the [[League of Prizren]] in 1878.]] {{See also|League of Prizren}} Prior to the [[Balkan wars]] of the beginning of the 20th century, Albanians were subjects of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. The Albanian independence movement emerged in 1878 with the [[League of Prizren]] (a council based in Kosovo) whose goal was cultural and political autonomy for ethnic Albanians inside the framework of the Ottoman Empire. However, the Ottomans were not prepared to grant The League's demands. Ottoman opposition to the League's cultural goals eventually helped transform it into an Albanian national movement.
Albanian nationalism overall was a reaction to the gradual breakup of the Ottoman Empire and a response to Balkan and Christian national movements that posed a threat to an Albanian population that was mainly Muslim.<ref name="PutoMaurizio183"/> Efforts were devoted to including vilayets with an Albanian population into a larger unitary Albanian autonomous province within the Ottoman state while Greater Albania was not considered a priority.<ref name="PutoMaurizio183"/><ref name="ShawShaw288"/><ref name="Kostov40">{{harvnb|Kostov|2010|p=40}}. "These scholars did not have access to many primary sources to be able to construct the notion of the Illyrian origin of the Albanians yet, and Greater Albania was not a priority. The goal of the day was to persuade the Ottoman officials that Albanians were a nation and they deserved some autonomy with the Empire. In fact, Albanian historians and politicians were very moderate compared to their peers in neighbouring countries.</ref> Albanian nationalism during the late Ottoman era was not imbued with separatism that aimed to create an Albanian nation-state, though Albanian nationalists did envisage an independent Greater Albania.<ref name="Austin237"/><ref name="PutoMaurizio183"/><ref name="Goldwyn276">{{harvnb|Goldwyn|2016|p=276}}.</ref> Albanian nationalists were mainly focused on defending rights that were sociocultural, historic and linguistic within existing countries without being connected to a particular polity.<ref name="PutoMaurizio183">{{harvnb|Puto|Maurizio|2015|p=183}}."Nineteenth-century Albanianism was not by any means a separatist project based on the desire to break with the Ottoman Empire and to create a nationstate. In its essence Albanian nationalism was a reaction to the gradual disintegration of the Ottoman Empire and a response to the threats posed by Christian and Balkan national movements to a population that was predominantly Muslim. In this sense, its main goal was to gather all ‘Albanian’ vilayet's into an autonomous province inside the Ottoman Empire. In fact, given its focus on the defence of the language, history and culture of a population spread across various regions and states, from Italy to the Balkans, it was not associated with any specific type of polity, but rather with the protection of its rights within the existing states. This was due to the fact that, culturally, early Albanian nationalists belonged to a world in which they were at home, though poised between different languages, cultures, and at times even states."</ref><ref name="ShawShaw288">{{harvnb|Shaw|Shaw|1977|p=288}}.</ref>
=== Balkan Wars and Albanian Independence (1912–1913) === The imminence of collapsing Ottoman rule through military defeat during the Balkan wars pushed Albanians represented by [[Ismail Qemali]] to [[Albanian Declaration of Independence|declare independence]] (28 November 1912) in [[Vlorë]] from the Ottoman Empire.<ref name="Gawrych197200" /> The main motivation for independence was to prevent Balkan Albanian inhabited lands from being annexed by Greece and Serbia.<ref name="Gawrych197200">{{harvnb|Gawrych|2006|pp=197–200}}.</ref><ref name="Fischera19">{{harvnb|Fischer|2007a|p=19}}.</ref> Italy and Austria-Hungary supported Albanian independence due to their concerns that Serbia with an Albanian coast would be a rival power in the Adriatic Sea and open to influence from its ally Russia.<ref name="Vickers6976">{{harvnb|Vickers|2011|pp=69–76}}.</ref><ref name="Tanner168172">{{harvnb|Tanner|2014|pp=168–172}}.</ref><ref name="Despot137">{{harvnb|Despot|2012|p=137}}.</ref><ref name="Kronenbitter85">{{harvnb|Kronenbitter|2006|p=85}}.</ref><ref name="Ker-Lindsay89">{{harvnb|Ker-Lindsay|2009|pp=8–9}}.</ref><ref name="Jelavich100103">{{harvnb|Jelavich|1983|pp=100–103}}.</ref><ref name="Guy453">{{harvnb|Guy|2007|p=453}}.</ref><ref name="Fischera21">{{harvnb|Fischer|2007a|p=21}}.</ref> Apart from geopolitical interests, some Great powers were reluctant to include more Ottoman Balkan Albanian inhabited lands into Albania due to concerns that it would be the only Muslim dominated state in Europe.<ref name="Volkan237">{{harvnb|Volkan|2004|p=237}}.</ref> Russo-French proposals were for a truncated Albania based on central Albania with a mainly Muslim population, which was also supported by Serbia and Greece who considered that only Muslims could only be Albanians.<ref name="Guy454">{{harvnb|Guy|2007|p=454}}. "Benckendorff, on the other hand, proposed only a truncated coastal strip to form a central Muslim dominated Albania, in accordance with the common view amongst Slavs, and also Greeks, that only Muslims could be considered Albanian (and not even Muslims necessarily)."</ref> As more Albanians became part of the Serbian and Greek states, Albanian scholars with nationalistic perspectives interpret the declaration of independence as a partial victory for the Albanian nationalist movement.<ref name="Gingeras31">{{harvnb|Gingeras|2009|p=31}}.</ref>
=== World War II === {{see also|Albanian Kingdom (1939–43)|World War II in Albania}} [[File:Map of Albania during WWII.png|thumb|150px|left|The Italian Protectorate of Albania established by Italy in August 1941.]]
On 7 April 1939, Italy headed by [[Benito Mussolini]] after prolonged interest and overarching sphere of influence during the interwar period [[Italian invasion of Albania|invaded Albania]].<ref name="Fischer52125">{{harvnb|Fischer|1999|pp=5, 21–25}}.</ref> Italian fascist regime members such as Count [[Galeazzo Ciano]] pursued Albanian irredentism with the view that it would earn Italians support among Albanians while also coinciding with Italian war aims of Balkan conquest.<ref name="Fischer7071">{{harvnb|Fischer|1999|pp=70-71}}.</ref> The Italian annexation of Kosovo to Albania was considered a popular action by Albanians of both areas.<ref name="Fischer88260">{{harvnb|Fischer|1999|pp=88,260}}.</ref> Western Macedonia was also annexed by Italy to their protectorate of Albania.<ref name="Hall183">{{harvnb|Hall|2010|p=183}}.</ref><ref name="Judah47">{{harvnb|Judah|2008|p=47}}.</ref> In newly acquired territories, non-Albanians had to attend Albanian schools that taught a curriculum containing nationalism alongside fascism and were made to adopt Albanian forms for their names and surnames.<ref name="Rossos185186"/> Members from the landowning elite, liberal nationalists opposed to communism with other sectors of society in Albania came to form the [[Balli Kombëtar]] organisation and the collaborationist government under the Italians which all as nationalists sought to preserve Greater Albania.<ref name="Fischer115116260">{{harvnb|Fischer|1999|pp=115-116, 260}}.</ref><ref name="Ramet141142">{{harvnb|Ramet|2006|pp=141-142}}.</ref><ref name="Rossos185186">{{harvnb|Rossos|2013|pp=185-186}}.</ref>
Many Kosovo Albanians were preoccupied with driving out the [[Kosovo Serbs|Serb minority]], particularly the post-1919 [[Yugoslav colonisation of Kosovo|Serbian and Montenegrin colonists]],{{sfn|Fischer|1999|p=237}} often settled on confiscated Albanian land (although the Albanians themselves had confiscated land and brutally abused during the last Ottoman years, as is well-documented).{{sfn|Denitch|1996|p=118}} Albanians saw Serbian and Yugoslav rule as foreign,{{sfn|Denitch|1996|p=118}} and according to Ramet they felt that anything would be better than the chauvinism, corruption, administrative hegemonism and exploitation they had experienced under the Serbian authorities.{{sfn|Ramet|2006|p=114}} Albanians collaborated broadly with the Axis occupiers, who had promised them a Greater Albania.{{sfn|Denitch|1996|p=118}} Collapse of Yugoslav rule resulted in actions of revenge being undertaken by Albanians, some joining the local ''[[Vulnetari]]'' militia that burned Serbian settlements and killed Serbs while interwar Serbian and Montenegrin colonists were expelled into [[Territory of the Military Commander in Serbia|Serbia]] proper.<ref name="Judah27">{{harvnb|Judah|2002|p=27}}.</ref><ref name="Ramon262"/><ref name="Judah47"/> The aim of these actions were to create a homogeneous Greater Albanian state.<ref name="Ramon262">{{harvnb|Ramón|2015|p=262}}.</ref> Italian authorities in Kosovo allowed the use of the Albanian language in schools, university education and administration.<ref name="Fontana92">{{harvnb|Fontana|2017|p=92}}.</ref> The same nationalist sentiments among Albanians which welcomed the addition of Kosovo and its Albanians within an enlarged state also worked against the Italians as foreign occupation became increasingly rejected in Albania.<ref name="Fischer260">{{harvnb|Fischer|1999|p=260}}.</ref> An attempt to get Kosovan Albanians to join the resistance, a meeting in Bujan (1943-1944), northern Albania was convened between Balli Kombëtar members and Albanian communists that agreed to common struggle and maintenance of the newly expanded boundaries.<ref name="Judah2930"/> The deal was opposed by Yugoslav partisans and later rescinded resulting in limited Kosovan Albanian recruits.<ref name="Judah2930">{{harvnb|Judah|2002|pp=29-30}}.</ref> Some Balli Kombëtar members such as [[Shaban Polluzha]] became partisans with the view that Kosovo would become part of Albania.<ref name="Judah30"/> With the end of the war, some of those Kosovan Albanians felt betrayed by the return of Yugoslav rule and for several years Albanian nationalists in Kosovo resisted both the partisans and later the new Yugoslav army.<ref name="Denitch118">{{harvnb|Denitch|1996|p=118}}.</ref><ref name="Judah30">{{harvnb|Judah|2002|pp=30}}.</ref><ref name="Turnock447">{{harvnb|Turnock|2004|pp=447}}.</ref> Albanian nationalists viewed their inclusion within Yugoslavia as an occupation.<ref name="BatkovskiRajkocevski95">{{harvnb|Batkovski|Rajkocevski|2014|p=95}}.</ref>
The [[Albanian Fascist Party]] became the ruling party of the Italian Protectorate of Albania in 1939 and the prime minister [[Shefqet Verlaci]] approved the possible administrative union of Albania and Italy, because he wanted the Italian support in order to get the union of [[Kosovo]], [[Chameria]] and other "Albanian irredentism" into ''Greater Albania''. Indeed, this unification was realized after the [[Axis powers|Axis]] occupation of [[Yugoslavia]] and [[Greece]] from spring 1941. The Albanian fascists claimed in May 1941 that nearly all the Albanian populated territories were united to Albania.<ref name="Zolo24">{{harvnb|Zolo|2002|p=24}}. "It was under the Italian and German occupation of 1939-1944 that the project of Greater Albania... was conceived."</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://terkepek.adatbank.transindex.ro/kepek/netre/226.gif|title=see map|author=|date=|website=transindex.ro|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226114618/http://terkepek.adatbank.transindex.ro/kepek/netre/226.gif|archivedate=26 February 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Between May 1941 and September 1943, [[Benito Mussolini]] placed nearly all the land inhabited by ethnic Albanians under the jurisdiction of an Albanian quisling government. That included the region of Kosovo, parts of the Republic of Macedonia and some small border areas of [[Montenegro]]. In [[Chameria]] an Albanian high commissioner, [[Xhemil Dino]], was appointed by the Italians; but the area remained under the control of the Italian military command in [[Athens]] and so technically remained a region of [[Greece]].
When the Germans occupied the area and substituted the Italians, they maintained the borders created by Mussolini, but after [[World War II]] the Albanian borders were returned by the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] to the pre-war status. [[File:AlbaniansOutsideAlbania.png|thumb|Distribution of Albanians in the Balkans.]]
=== Yugoslav Wars === {{main|Insurgency in Kosovo (1992–98)|Kosovo War|Insurgency in the Preševo Valley|2001 insurgency in the Republic of Macedonia}} The [[Kosovo Liberation Army]] (KLA) was an ethnic-Albanian [[paramilitary]] organisation which sought the separation of Kosovo from [[FR Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] during the 1990s and the eventual creation of a ''Greater Albania'', encompassing Kosovo, Albania, and the ethnic Albanian minority of neighbouring [[Republic of Macedonia]]. The KLA found great moral and financial support among the Albanian diaspora.<ref>{{cite web|title=State-building in Kosovo. A plural policing perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YS15BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA53|publisher=Maklu|date=5 February 2015|p=53}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Liberating Kosovo: Coercive Diplomacy and U. S. Intervention |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X5sa90AEvi0C&pg=PA69|publisher=[[Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]]|date=2012|p=69}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dictionary of Genocide |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rgGA91skoP4C&pg=PA249|publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]]|date=2008|p=249}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA)|url=http://www.britannica.com/topic/Kosovo-Liberation-Army|publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]|date=14 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906171517/http://www.britannica.com/topic/Kosovo-Liberation-Army|archivedate=6 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Albanian Insurgents Keep NATO Forces Busy|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,101938,00.html|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=6 March 2001|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161226173544/http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,101938,00.html|archivedate=26 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
KLA Commander [[Sylejman Selimi]] insisted:<ref>{{cite web|title=Liberating Kosovo: Coercive Diplomacy and U. S. Intervention |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X5sa90AEvi0C&lpg=PA69&dq=greater%20albania%20kla&hl=sr&pg=PR7#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=[[Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]]|date=2012|p=69}}</ref> {{cquote|There is ''de facto'' Albanian nation. The tragedy is that European powers after [[World War I]] decided to divide that nation between several Balkan states. We are now fighting to unify the nation, to liberate all Albanians, including those in Macedonia, Montenegro, and other parts of Serbia. We are not just a liberation army for Kosovo.}}
By 1998 the KLA’s operations had evolved into a significant armed insurrection. According to the report of the [[U.S. Committee for Refugees and Immigrants|USCRI]], the "Kosovo Liberation Army ... attacks aimed at trying to 'cleanse' Kosovo of its ethnic Serb population." The [[UNHCR]] estimated the figure at 55,000 refugees who had fled to [[Montenegro]] and [[Central Serbia]], most of whom were [[Kosovo Serbs]].<ref name="Allan178">{{harvnb|Allan|Zelizer|2004|p=178}}.</ref>
Its campaign against [[Serbia and Montenegro|Yugoslav]] security forces, police, government officers and ethnic Serb villages precipitated a major [[Army of Yugoslavia (Federal Republic of Yugoslavia)|Yugoslav military]] crackdown which led to the [[Kosovo War]] of 1998–1999. Military intervention by Yugoslav security forces led by [[Slobodan Milošević]] and Serb paramilitaries within Kosovo prompted an exodus of Kosovar Albanians and a refugee crisis that eventually caused [[NATO]] to intervene militarily in order to stop what was widely identified as an ongoing campaign of [[ethnic cleansing]].<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/reports/2001/kosovo/undword-03.htm UNDER ORDERS: War Crimes in Kosovo – 4. March–June 1999: An Overview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121203092331/http://www.hrw.org/reports/2001/kosovo/undword-03.htm |date=3 December 2012 }}. Hrw.org. Retrieved on 14 March 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990DE3D81F31F937A15750C0A96F958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | title=Conflict In The Balkans: The Overview; Nato Authorizes Bomb Strikes; Primakov, In Air, Skips U.S. Visit | first=Jane | last=Perlez | date=24 March 1999 | accessdate=4 April 2010}}</ref>
The war ended with the [[Kumanovo Treaty]], with Yugoslav forces agreeing to withdraw from Kosovo to make way for an international presence.<ref name="chrono">{{cite web|title=Kosovo war chronology|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|url=https://www.hrw.org/campaigns/kosovo98/timeline.shtml|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828081512/http://www.hrw.org/campaigns/kosovo98/timeline.shtml|archivedate=28 August 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2012/11/balkan-wars|accessdate=26 February 2013|title=The Balkan wars: Reshaping the map of 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Kosovo Liberation Army disbanded soon after this, with some of its members going on to fight for the [[Liberation Army of Preševo, Medveđa and Bujanovac|UÇPMB]] in the veterans linked to latest bout of violence in Macedonia|first=Justin|last=Huggler|date=12 March 2001|accessdate=4 April October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== 2000s–present === Political parties advocating and willing to fight for a Greater Albania emerged in Albania during the 2000s.<ref name="Stojarova49" /> They were the National Liberation Front of Albanians (KKCMTSH) and Party of National Unity (PUK) that both merged in 2002 to form the United National Albanian Front (FBKSh) which acted as the political organisation for the [[Albanian National Army]] (AKSh) militant group and consisted of some disaffected KLA and NLA members.<ref name="BanksMullerOverstreet22" /><ref name="Stojarova49" /> Regarded internationally as terrorist both have gone underground and its members have been involved in various violent incidents in Kosovo, Serbia and Macedonia during the 2000s.<ref name="BanksMullerOverstreet22">{{harvnb|Banks|Muller|Overstreet|2010|p=22}}.</ref><ref name="Schmid401">{{harvnb|Schmid|2011|p=401}}.</ref><ref name="KoktsidisDam180">{{harvnb|Koktsidis|Dam|2008|p=180}}.</ref> In the early 2000s, the [[Liberation Army of Chameria]] (UCC) was a reported paramilitary formation that intended to be active in northern Greek region of [[Epirus (region)|Epirus]].<ref name="Vickers1213">{{harvnb|Vickers|2002|p=12-13}}.</ref><ref name="Stojarova96">{{harvnb|Stojarová|2016|p=96}}.</ref> Political parties active only in the political scene exist that have a nationalist outlook are the monarchist [[Legality Movement Party]] (PLL), the [[National Unity Party (Albania)|National Unity Party]] (PBKSh) alongside the Balli Kombëtar, a party to have passed the electoral threshold and enter parliament.<ref name="Stojarova49" /><ref name="Austin246" /> These political parties, some of whom advocate for a Greater Albania have been mainly insignificant and remained at the margins of the Albanian political scene.<ref name="Austin246" /> The Kosovo question has limited appeal among Albanian voters and are not interested in electing parties advocating redrawn borders creating a Greater Albania.<ref name="Stojarova49">{{harvnb|Stojarova|2010|p=49}}.</ref> Centenary Albanian independence celebrations in 2012 generated nationalistic commentary among the political elite of whom prime-minister [[Sali Berisha]] referred to Albanian lands as extending to [[Preveza]], northern Greece and [[Preševo]], southern Serbia angering Albania's neighbors.<ref name="Endresen208b">{{harvnb|Endresen|2016|p=208}}.</ref> In Kosovo, a prominent left wing nationalist movement turned political party [[Vetëvendosje]] (Self Determination) has emerged who advocates for closer Kosovo-Albania relations and pan-Albanian self determination in the Balkans.<ref name="Schwartz111112">{{harvnb|Schwartz|2014|pp=111-112}}.</ref><ref name="Venner75">{{harvnb|Venner|2016|p=75}}.</ref> Another smaller nationalist party, the Balli Kombetar Kosovë (BKK) sees itself as an heir to the original Second World War organisation that supports Kosovan independence and pan-Albanian unification.<ref name="Stojarova49" /> Greater Albania remains mainly in the sphere of political rhetoric and overall Balkan Albanians view EU integration as the solution to combat crime, weak governance, civil society and bringing different Albanian populations together.<ref name="Merdjanova49">{{harvnb|Merdjanova|2013|p=49}}.</ref><ref name="Austin246">{{harvnb|Austin|2004|p=246}}.</ref>
== Political uses of the concept == The Albanian question in the Balkan peninsula is in part the consequence of the decisions made by Western powers in late 19th and early 20th century. The [[Treaty of San Stefano]] and the [[Treaty of Berlin (1878)|1878 Treaty of Berlin]] assigned Albanian inhabited territories to other States, hence the reaction of the League of Prizren.<ref name="Jelavich361">{{harvnb|Jelavich|1983|pp=361}}.</ref> One theory posits that the [[United Kingdom]], [[France]], [[Germany]], and [[Austro-Hungary]] wanted to maintain a brittle balance in Europe in the late 19th century.{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}}
The degree to which different groups are working towards.and what efforts such groups are undertaking in order to achieve a Greater Albania is disputed. There seems no evidence that anything more than a few unrepresentative extremist groups are working towards this cause; the vast majority of Albanians want to live in peace with their neighbors. However, they also want the human rights of the Albanian ethnic populations in Republic of Macedonia, Serbia, Greece to be respected. An excellent example is the friendly relationship between the [[Republic of Montenegro]] and the support towards the integration of the Albanian population in Republic of Macedonia. There is Albanian representation in government, the national parliament, local government, and the business sector, and no evidence of systematic discrimination on an ethnic or religious basis against the Albanian (or indeed any other minority) population.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}
In 2000, the then-[[US Secretary of State]] Madeleine Albright said that the international community would not tolerate any efforts towards the creation of a Greater Albania.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/648630.stm | work=BBC News | title=Albright warns Albania against expansion | date=19 February 2000 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022105856/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/648630.stm | archivedate=22 October 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2004, the [[Vetëvendosje]] movement was formed in [[Kosovo]], which opposes foreign involvement in Kosovan affairs and campaigns instead for the sovereignty the people, as part of the right of self-determination. Vetëvendosje obtained 12.66% of the votes in an election in December 2010, and the party manifesto calls for a referendum on union with Albania.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lëvizja Vetëvendosje |url=http://vetevendosje.org/repository/docs/Programme_Politique_Version_Courte.pdf |publisher=Lëvizja Vetëvendosje |accessdate=1 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
In 2012, the [[Red and Black Alliance]] ({{lang-sq|Aleanca Kuq e Zi}}) was established as a political party in Albania, the core of its program is national unification of all Albanians in their native lands.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aleanca Kuq e Zi|url=http://www.aleancakuqezi.al|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111017163330/http://www.aleancakuqezi.al/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 October 2011|accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref>
In 2012, as part of the celebrations for [[100th Anniversary of the Independence of Albania]], Prime Minister Sali Berisha spoke of "Albanian lands" stretching from [[Preveza]] in Greece to [[Presevo]] in Serbia, and from the Macedonian capital of [[Skopje]] to the Montenegrin capital of [[Podgorica]], angering Albania's neighbors. The comments were also inscribed on a parchment that will be displayed at a museum in the city of Vlore, where the country’s independence from the Ottoman Empire was declared in 1912.<ref>''Albania celebrates 100 years of independence, yet angers half its neighbors'' Associated Press, November 28, 2012.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/albania-celebrates-100-years-of-independence-yet-angers-half-its-neighbors/2012/11/28/a17de6d4-398a-11e2-9258-ac7c78d5c680_print.html]</ref>

===Kosovo=== {{Main|Albanians in Kosovo|Republic of Kosovo|Kosovo's unification with Albania}}
Kosovo has an overwhelmingly Albanian majority, estimated to be around 92%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/kv.html|last=CIA|accessdate=27 July 2010|title=The World Factbook|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080306223735/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/kv.html|archivedate=6 March 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Montenegro=== {{Main|Albanians in Montenegro}}
The irredentist claims in Montenegro are in the border areas, including [[Skadarska Krajina|Kraja]], [[Ulcinj]], [[Tuzi]] ([[Malësia]]), [[Plav Municipality|Plav and Gusinje]], and [[Rožaje]] ([[Sandžak]]).<ref name="Petranović2002">{{cite book|author=Branko Petranović|title=The Yugoslav Experience of Serbian National Integration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SoVpAAAAMAAJ|year=2002|publisher=East European Monographs|isbn=978-0-88033-484-6|quote=... unite with Albania, and to form the second Albanian state outside Yugoslavia, which would gather the Albanians of Kosovo and Metohija, western Macedonia and the border regions of Montenegro from Plav, Gusinje and Rozaje, through Tuzi, near the Montenegrin capital, the hinterland of Lake Skadar (Krajina) up to Ulcinj.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Kenneth Morrison|title=Nationalism, Identity and Statehood in Post-Yugoslav Montenegro|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GZw8DwAAQBAJ&pg=PT36|date=11 January 2018|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4742-3520-4|p=36|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180510022533/https://books.google.com/books?id=GZw8DwAAQBAJ&pg=PT36|archivedate=10 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to the 2011 census, the Albanian proportion in those municipalities are following: Ulcinj–14,076 (70%), Tuzi–2,383 (50%), Plav–(19%), Rožaje–188 (2%). The claim on the Sandžak area, where the Albanian community is small and the Bosniak community is the majority, is based on the Albanian state borders in World War II and presence in the late Ottoman period.
===Republic of Macedonia=== {{See also|Albanians in Republic of Macedonia|2001 insurgency in the Republic of Macedonia}}
The western part of the Republic of Macedonia is an area with a large ethnic Albanian minority. The Albanian population in Republic of Macedonia make up 25% of the population, numbering 509,083 in the 2002 census.<ref name=Statisticaloffice>Macedonian Census (2002), [http://www.stat.gov.mk/publikacii/knigaX.pdf ''Book 5 - Total population according to the Ethnic Affiliation, Mother Tongue and Religion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327022959/http://www.stat.gov.mk/publikacii/knigaX.pdf |date=27 March 2014 }}'', The State Statistical Office, Skopje, 2002, p. 62.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mk.html|title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency|author=|date=|website=www.cia.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091114103245/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mk.html|archivedate=14 November 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Cities with Albanian majorities or large minorities include [[Tetovo]] (Tetova), [[Gostivar]] (Gostivari), [[Struga]] (Struga) and [[Debar]] (Diber).<ref>Unrepresented Nations & Peoples Organization, Yearbook 1995 Page 41 By Mary Kate Simmons {{ISBN|90-411-0223-X}}</ref>
In the 1980s, Albanian irredentist organizations appeared in Macedonia, particularly Vinica, Kicevo, Tetovo and Gostivar.<ref name="Ramet1995">{{cite book|author=Sabrina P. Ramet|title=Social Currents in Eastern Europe: The Sources and Consequences of the Great Transformation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F3HTHpikwq4C&pg=PA203|year=1995|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=0-8223-1548-3|pages=203–|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180510022533/https://books.google.com/books?id=F3HTHpikwq4C&pg=PA203|archivedate=10 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 1992, Albanian activists in Struga proclaimed also the founding of the [[Republic of Ilirida]] ({{lang-sq|Republika e Iliridës}})<ref name="Ramet80">{{harvnb|Ramet|1997|p=80}}.</ref> with the intention of autonomy or federalization inside the Republic of Macedonia. The declaration had only a symbolic meaning and the idea of an autonomous State of Ilirida is not officially accepted by the ethnic Albanian politicians in the Republic of Macedonia.<ref name="Bugajski116">{{harvnb|Bugajski|1994|pp=116}}.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/1100499.html|title=Macedonia: Authorities Allege Existence Of New Albanian Rebel Group|author=|date=|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170712072345/https://www.rferl.org/a/1100499.html|archivedate=12 July 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Preševo Valley=== {{Main|Albanians in Serbia}}
The irredentist claims in [[Central Serbia|Serbia proper]] (excluding Kosovo) are in the southern [[Preševo Valley]], including municipalities of [[Preševo]] ({{lang-sq|Preshevë}}), [[Bujanovac]] ({{lang-sq|Bujanoc}}) and partially [[Medveđa]] ({{lang-sq|Medvegjë}}), where there is an Albanian community. In 2001, the Albanians were estimated to have numbered 70,000 in the area.<ref name="Presevo valley tension">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1043583.stm|title=Presevo valley tension|date=2 February 2001|last=Partos|first=Gabriel|work=[[BBC]]|accessdate=14 January 2015|quote=Initially, the guerrillas' publicly acknowledged objective was to protect the local ethnic Albanian population of some 70,000 people from the repressive actions of the Serb security forces.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023192256/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1043583.stm|archivedate=23 October 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to the 2002 census, the Albanian proportion in those municipalities were following: Preševo–31,098 (89%), Bujanovac–23,681 (55%), Medveđa–2,816 (26%).
Following the [[Kosovo War]] (1998–99), the Albanian separatist [[Liberation Army of Preševo, Medveđa and Bujanovac]] ({{lang-sq|Ushtria Çlirimtare e Preshevës, Medvegjës dhe Bujanocit}}, UÇPMB), fought an insurgency against the Serbian government, aiming to seceding the Preševo Valley into Kosovo.<ref name="ReuvenyThompson2010">{{cite book|author1=Rafael Reuveny|author2=William R. Thompson|title=Coping with Terrorism: Origins, Escalation, Counterstrategies, and Responses|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LkeKIYW0sXkC&pg=PA185|date=5 November 2010|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-1-4384-3313-4|pages=185–}}</ref>
===Greece=== {{Main|Chameria|Cham Albanians}}
The irredentist claim in Greece are [[Chameria]], parts of [[Epirus (region)|Epirus]], the historical [[Vilayet of Janina]].<ref name="Merdjanova147">{{harvnb|Merdjanova|2013|p=147}}.</ref>{{qn|date=April 2014}}<ref name="Kola15"/><ref name="Seton-Watson189">{{harvnb|Seton-Watson|1917|p=189}}.</ref>{{qn|date=April 2014}}<ref name="Austin237">{{harvnb|Austin|2004|p=237}}.</ref>{{qn|date=April 2014}}<ref name="Vaknin102103">{{harvnb|Vaknin|2000|pp=102-103}}.</ref>{{qn|date=April 2014}}
The coastal region of [[Thesprotia]] in northwestern [[Greece]] referred to by Albanians as ''[[Chameria|Çamëria]]'' is sometimes included in Greater Albania.<ref name="BogdaniLoughlin230">{{harvnb|Bogdani|Loughlin|2007|pp=230}}.</ref> According to the 1928 census held by the Greek state, there were around 20,000 Muslim Cams in [[Thesprotia|Thesprotia prefecture]]. They were forced to seek refuge in Albania at the end of World War II after a large part of them [[Axis-Cham Albanian collaboration|collaborated]] and committed a number of crimes together with the Nazis during the 1941–1944 period.<ref name="Meyer702">{{harvnb|Meyer|2008|p=702}}.</ref> In the first post-war census (1951), only 123 Muslim Çams were left in the area. Descendants of the exiled Muslim Chams (they claim that they are now up to 170,000 now living in Albania) claim that up to 35,000 Muslim Çams were living in southern Epirus before World War II. Many of them are currently trying to pursue legal ways to claim compensation for the properties seized by Greece. For Greece the issue "does not exist".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.da.mod.uk/colleges/csrc/document-listings/balkan/07%2801%29MV.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626234836/http://www.da.mod.uk/colleges/csrc/document-listings/balkan/07%2801%29MV.pdf |archivedate=26 June 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Despite the Cham-induced controversy, during a visit to Albania in mid-October 2004, Greek President Konstantinos Stephanopoulos stated at a news conference that the Cham issue did not exist for Greece and that claims for the restoration of property presented by both the Cham people and the Greek minority in Albania belonged to a past historical period which he considered closed. "I don't know if it is necessary to find a solution to the Cham issue, as in my opinion it does not need to be solved," he said. "There have been claims from both sides, but we should not return to these matters. The question of the Cham properties does not exist," he said. When speaking of claims from both sides, Stephanopoulos was referring (also) to the Greek claims over Northern Epirus, which include a considerable part of southern Albania.</ref>
==International Crisis Group research== [[International Crisis Group]] researched the issue of Pan-Albanianism and published a report titled "Pan-Albanianism: How Big a Threat to Balkan Stability?" on February 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.da.mod.uk/colleges/csrc/document-listings/balkan/07%2801%29MV.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626234836/http://www.da.mod.uk/colleges/csrc/document-listings/balkan/07%2801%29MV.pdf |archivedate=26 June 2008 |df=dmy-all }} "Cham demonstrators was enough to galvanise Greece into defensive mode. The country embarked upon a series of military and diplomatic initiatives, which suggested a fear of Pan-Albanian expansion towards north-western Greece. Serbian and Macedonian media reports were claiming that new Pan-Albanian organisations were planning to expand their operations into north-western Greece to include Meanwhile, Chameria in their plans for the unification of "all Albanian territories." international observers were concerned that Kosovo politicians might start speculating with the Cham issue. The report observed that the "notions of pan-Albanianism are far more layered and complex than the usual broad brush characterisations of ethnic Albanians simply bent on achieving a greater Albania or a greater Kosovo." Furthermore, the report stated that amongst Albanians, "violence in the cause of a greater Albania, or of any shift of borders, is neither politically popular nor morally justified."</ref>
The International Crisis Group advised in the report the Albanian and Greek governments to endeavour and settle the longstanding issue of the Chams displaced from Greece in 1945, before it gets hijacked and exploited by extreme nationalists, and the Chams' legitimate grievances get lost in the struggle to further other national causes. Moreover, the ICG findings suggest that Albania is more interested in developing cultural and economic ties with Kosovo and maintaining separate statehood.<ref>[http://www.crisisgroup.org/home/index.cfm?id=2523&l=1 Pan-Albanianism: How Big a Threat to Balkan Stability?, Europe Report N°153, 25 February 2004] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509145704/http://www.crisisgroup.org/home/index.cfm?l=1&id=2523 |date=9 May 2007 }}</ref>

{{hatnote|This article is about the Scottish land tenure. For the Greek unit of measure, see [[Greek units|Ancient Greek]] and [[Byzantine units]].}} '''Half-foot''' ({{lang-gd|leth-chois}}, {{lang-sco|hauf-fit}}) was a kind of [[land tenure]] peculiar to northern and western [[Scotland]].
The possessor, generally impoverished, or without facilities for working the land, often furnished the land and seed corn, and the tenant cultivated it, the produce being equally divided between them. There have been instances of it in the 20th century.
Other uses: * A certain stage in the drying of [[peat]]s. * Part of a hand line
